content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has a LOT of people either in love with it, or not understanding how anyone could enjoy it.  Both ends of the scale have pretty good reasons for their decision.  The word potential gets thrown around quite a bit with this game, that's because it does have absurd potential for being massively awesome, but let's just focus on fixing the crashes first (they are much less frequent than they used to be, but still).  Crashing out of the game isnt that bad, the game autosaves already fairly frequently, and you can even increase how often it autosaves.  The combat is quite unique in that you dont directly control your squad while they fight, but their skills dictate how well they do.  Once you see a couple of well trained soldiers quickly work through an army of low skill bandits, you understand how awesome fighting can get.  But I do mean "can get", as you have to work your♥♥♥♥♥off trying to not get the crap kicked out of your guys until they can hold your own even against a few other enemies.  The game also has a basebuilding mechanic, with research and crafting, but in all honesty I haven't attempted it beyond "I'm gonna build a house on this lovely mouintain", so I don't really know how it all plays out or if it's even working.  The game has a cool trading method, go from town to town buying things for cheap and reselling them at the next town over where they don't have those items so you can sell 'em for a higher markup.  There are multiple starts in Kenshi, from being a naked man with a roughed up arm in the middle of the desert to 5 guys wanting to start a town, there are multiple fun ways to start the game off.  Character creation in Kenshi is interesting to say the least, it's not awful, but a lot of the sliders you just don't want to touch for risk of making your character very disproportionate so the armours and weapons dont look quite right.  I once made a midget named Hugo who wielded the biggest blade I could find, it always hovered near his hands and not in them.  Out of 352 games I can honestly say this game is one of my favourites, Kenshi is quite the experience and I feel like I didn't do the game justice with this review, because its either a game that you will love, or you'll disregard it forever.

number of helpful: 17 of 22 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is THE game for a gamer who is seriously into strategy/simulation.  I bought Kenshi on the steam sale, and instantly became hooked.  There is no friendly, happy, bunny mode.  You begin in one of the scenarios you choose. i.e. your starting squad and loadout, and instantly begin in an unforgiving world of sand ninjas, samurai, and desert drifters.  How you choose to proceed is up to you, and if you choose unwisely, you will die/fail.  No one to blame but your past.  If you don't rush into the desert wastes, put some thought into you development, and plan, there is a great chance you will succeed ... or at least not be bludgeoned too bad by hungry bandits.  Wait and admass a squad and income before trying to form your own town and you will be okay; if not you will have to fight like clint eastwood in an old western, but without the guys.  Great game for those with the patience to play it and overlook the occasional bug.  On this issue, updates are constantly coming out, and fixes come out even faster.  The Dev is doing a great job for it's small operation, and if you can handle the occasional stress of dealing with a bug and at the worst having to revert to the newest save or auto save, there is nothing too flawed about the game.I highly recommend it for any serious gamer.  If you can handle anything but immediate gratification, don't buy it; plain and simple. Just call downstairs to your mom for some more soda and pizza bites ... everything will be okay snookums’.

Early Access Review
								I discovered Kenshi five days ago. I have only been playing Kenshi for five days now.First and foremost: the game has many flaws. It's in beta and the bugs are numerous. You'll need to restart the game to alleviate some of these bugs, while others will need to be remedied by verifying the game cache.But it's all worth it.Kenshi draws me in and tickles a nostalgic part of my brain that is still in love with Star Wars Galaxies (pre combat revamp of course). The combat seems clunky at first but really just takes time to appreciate. You are not spoon fed. Your characters will be wounded, ensalved, imprisoned and killed. And you'll continually become stronger and smarter because of it.Building your own camp is fun. Turning that into a village is great. Becoming the architect of your own city that can be seen from the alien horizon is what it's all about.Buy this game at full price. Have some patience and allow Kenshi to grow on you. This is a special title. Don't miss out on it.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Wow, that guy has a 5000 cat bounty? Alright, I just recruited 2 people from a nearby bar and outfitted them with armor from that group of desperate, starving bandits. Its time to make some money!It's just one dude, we can take him."Retreat! Retreat!" as I fall with a katana buried in my back, blood staining the sand.Hours later, I awake. It's dusk. One of my companions lies merely a dozen yards from me, barely breathing. The other is no where to be found. I grit my teeth as I throw Brigand over my back and silently pace towards the city with as many samurai as citizens. The city lights are guiding me. I'm nearly there. I can see the light glint off of the helmets of the samurai warriors. Behind me, I hear footsteps. Many footsteps. As I turn, fifteen screaming bandits are taking positions around me. I drop Brigand to the sand and unsheath my rusty sword. In a moment, I feel a myriad of blades tear into my flesh. My vision started to swim and I could feel death creeping upon me, slowly yet surely. Another moment later, the bandits are routing as the Samurai crash into their ranks. With my last breaths, I carried my companion to the inn, and placed him on a bed. I didn't make it more than five feet before I feel to the ground. There just wasn't enough blood to keep me standing. May Brigand find better fortune than I in this world.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Why should you get this game? 84 hours in six days is not enough reason?Then let me tell you my Kenshi story:I never buy games which are not as special somewhere.So when I wanted to try Kenshi - again like some months or years ago - I got the demo from the website of the developer.When a demo exists it normally means that the developer thinks peoplewill like his product even after trying it. Self confidence.I tried the demo and played it for - I don't know - two or three days.Then I realized, I want the whole game, the actual update, I got the game,even if there was no special. I don't do that. Never. Normally.Demo play:I already know that I am not the hero in this game. So I know I have to take it slowly.I start in rags in a large desert. I run around until I get to a small village in the mountains.With all my money I hire a guy to follow me.Now we hang around town and whenever the town gets attacked we loot the bodies and sell the stuff.With the money I get more guys and some backpacks.During one of attacks one of the police officers dies.I take one look at his armor and weapon and decide: MINE!When I bring back the loot, walking proud in my new shiny armor a police officer yells at me:"Where did you get that armor?"Then he attacks me.My friends of course try to help me, but we are no match for the police officers of the village who regularly defend the village against large groups of villains.We lie there unconscious and bleeding with many wound to different parts of our bodies.After a while one of us becomes conscious again and treates himself and all of us until we are not bleeding anymore.Then he takes one of us on his shoulders, carries him to the next inn and puts him into a bed.Then he does it for the rest of us and at last puts himself to sleep too.The beds are kind of costly for me at this point so I decide I want my own house with some beds.The next days we just loot and save the money until we can buy a small house and put there some sleeping bags.Now we can use the accelerated healing rate of sleeping in a bag without having to pay for it.It is time to expand. We are so arrogant, we have no idea what we are going to get into.We take the best loot of some days as armor and weapons and some med kits and venture towards another city.Some time into the desert a horde of bandits comes running towards us.Ha, small game, we think. We saw them slaughtered on a daily basis at the village gates.They slaughter us. We lie there unconscious and bleeding with many wound to different parts of our bodies.Again.So, again the first of us who can move again starts healing the others.Then the bandits come back.They hit all walking guys again until they walk no more and start looting us.They take nearly everything.Then they march away.One comes running back and takes some more stuff from us before he follows his friends.We nearly don't make it back to the village. Some have to be carried, some can only hobble because they have serious wounds at their legs, some can not carry others because they have wounds at their arms.We were defeated but we are better in some areas like fighting and toughness.When we are able to move again I decide to go back to looting but I will send one guy without armor or weapons to run as fast as possible to the next city to start a second base there.While he is running down the next mountain some dogs start to chase him for a while and I am thinking I'll lose him.But he gets to the next city.I decide, I need the full game....The real game.Grass! Trees! Animals!Man, the difference is stunning.I start in a very small settlement of the Holy Nation, just two houses, some fields and a well.I have nothing and can't do a lot here but steal or attack and I want to be nice.So I decide to go to the next village.I wander the street when I encounter a patrol of the Holy Nation. Looks nice and powerfull that patrol.They approach me: "What god do you worship?"Me: "none".Wrong answer. They beat me senseless and continue their patrol. At least they did not try to loot me.Even if I have nothing, I don't like to get looted.Now I am angry. I limp parallel to the path back to the settlement.When I get near the settlement, I start to sneak and check for guys with weapons.I get back into the settlement, always ready to run, aehm limp, away.Everything is allowed now. I steal everything I can. I see one guy with a backpack. I want it. So I can steal more!Hitting people when I am sneaking gives me a chance to knock them out.That is the skill assassination. I am very bad at it.But the peasants of this evil religion will be the first receivers of my wrath.I train knocking people out until I am very good at it.Then I get my backpack. My first backpack. All mine.I gather (steal) some more things and again decide it is time to move to another location.This time I stay away from the street and move carefully through the wilderness.When I get to a village it is not a village but a city. Large walls around lots of large buildings and many heavily armed and armored guards at the entry.I approach them, fearing the worst. This time no questioning and no attacks.I move into the city and sell my stuff at the first vendor I find.Big mistake.He recognizes the stuff as stolen from his own empire and calls the guards.They beat me senseless AGAIN and put me into prison.A cage inside one of their military buildings.I pick the lock and run away.I hide from the guards until I am no longer "escaped" but just someone with a bounty.Not everyone reacts to bounties every time.For some money a guy will join me.Silly me. The first guy I hire is not a human so the whole "Holy Nation" hates him.Very often we get insulted, traders don't trade with him and sometimes he will just get attacked and imprisoned for not wanting to be rebirthed. No idea what it is, but it does not sound good.I started to live in this city but the racist religion here got on my nerves, I decided to get to another race which was supposed to live in the south.So I ran south, swam in the river, outrun bandits and animals.When I was out of food and my swimming skill had reached level 30 I reached the border of the currently reachable area. No other race. Via forum I found I had to go west. So to the west I went.Hills, deserts, bandits. The bandits got me. I survived and hobbled towards the area where I thought the other race to be.On the map I got a marker for a village of the other race. I was nearly there. Then I got attacked by a group of animals which ate me....New life.I am this time near a even smaller settlement.Nearby is some iron, so I decide to start a small settlement here.First I will need building materials.So I create a stone mine and start to build a machine which creates construction material from stone.Not enough construction material for the machine.I need money. I mine the ore mine and sell the ore to elder of the nearby settlement.The settlement is attacked very often by dogs and bandits, I just loot the bandits and dogs and cook the dog meat so I don't get hungry and everything is kind of right.While mining some ore I get attacked by two dogs, they make me bleed so bad, my status changes from "bleeding" to "dying", all the while being unconscious.A patrol of the Holy Nation marches on the nearby street, but I am out of sight for them. They march on.I die....New life.Because of the size of the story I have to link to a post, so if you wish to continue reading, go there:http://steamcommunity.com/app/233860/discussions/4/343788552533488306/

number of helpful: 68 of 116 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Disclaimer: as soon as the devs have finished this product, I will most likely change this recommendation to a whole-hearted "Yes."Kenshi is a game that contains much of what I've been wanting to see combined in open world rpgs for years: a totally open world, completely freeform squads, strategic gameplay with limb-damage, character progression, and the ability to easily break up or become seperated from your units. Actually, that last one was something I didn't even know I wanted until I played this game. In a game like Mount & Blade, failure means capture and the loss of most of your equipment and probably all of your units, and you are tied to the unit that captured you without options or variation. When my characters were knocked out by cannibals in Kenshi, my main character was left behind while the two units I had aquired by that point were taken to the cannibal's camp. Eventually, my character recovered enough to limp towards the nearest town, while my units were forced to despirately try to pick the locks of thier cages. One unit escaped, one didn't. The world of Kenshi allows for variation in losing, including the possibility of death for your main character if too much damage is taken. The result is strangly thrilling, and as I watched my unit desperately flee the cannibal camp with enemies running after her, I knew I had stumbled upon a game of great possibility.Unfortunitly, Kenshi remains too unfinished a possibility. The event I just described was the highlight of my several hours of playtime. At the moment there are no quests in Kenshi. You can build buildings, but there is no guarentee that the buildings will carry over to new versions of the game. My only goal is to build up the strength to get revenge for the unit that was killed by the cannibals. After that's done, I'll simply have no reason to keep playing.Buy only if you want to support the developers.Gameplay:

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								My first adventure in this game was one with lots of questions and involved a lot of reading on my part. Though the mechanics of  this game seem cruel I feel greatly rewarded when I survive an attack against bandits or get my characters' skills up.I had started as a survivor, looking at my war buddy as I woke from a losing battle. Though he looked to be healing alright he was still unconcious and we where a long ways from any city. It took some time for me to manag(figure out) how to carry the larger man but I had managed and began walking my way towards a city. I had noticed two bandit groups skirmishing just a little distance away from me.After getting to the city I was able to buy a mercenary to help me go and pick up some salvagable equipment from the battle that I had seen on the way over. WIth the money from that equipment I hired a medic and we waited for my friend to wake up. Two days later he wakes up and we set out for another town. Two more people joined up and we moved on to another town. After fending off some badits and sand ninjas he limped out way into the Holy City of Sharks where four more people joined up. We had a large group now so we thought it would be  smart idea to build our own city. Two days later in the middle of the desert we where lost to the sands.Though my group met a tragic end at the hands of cannibals I was still able to enjoy the hours long playthrough. I learned alot abou thta tfirst one and am going to put that to good use in my next playthrough. I would deffinately recommend this game to hardcore RPG and stategy game fans.Edit:PLaying this game on and off and loving every minute of it. The game gets better and better each time it's updated. Though I will say that I wish they would bring back certain scenarios such as the survivor one where you and an ally survive a fight. I found that one to be the most fun but I still enjoy the new content to a great deal. Keep up the good work and listening to the players!

Early Access Review
								They just did a fairly decent update, but after many months i'm not impressed.  Now if they ever fix it so npcs spawn in towns so you can hire more squad members instead of having to import to a new game everytime and then bugging your town such as the walls allowing npcs to walk through them after you import for example, would be a great first start. Until then, however....NO.  They said they plan to polish it and work on stabilizing soon someday, so maybe when they start doing that i can change my review back to yes as I had it when i first got the game and ignorant of how long this game has been in development, thinking it was just a couple weeks old and not 2 or 3 years at the time. So now we are heading into year 5?  I do like the game concept,gameplay and the genre of this kind. I believe this game is more likely to become abandoneware than a finished game as slow as its getting developed.  That is why I say NO.6/3/16. The last month included a lot of fixes and such, you still have to import your game to new game if you want to hire more squad members.  Prisoner cages are still bugged, you can pick lock them with prisoners, and they still ask to be set free even though its unlocked. Most of them don't even talk to you.  I just crashed the game by dismantling a small shack.  So although they keep adding new content, which is a plus for any game, except when they ignore fixing what they already have. So I must keep a no recommendation, until they show development that counts.6/15/16 New map, hurray! Now if you only play the game without it crashing. I can't say much for this update, since the game crashes soon after you start playing it. Maybe in a month or two or this fall they will have a fix for it.

Early Access Review
								From what I've consistently seen from early access games, as soon as they go on special, the creators lose any financial motivation to continue development. I rarely give bad reviews, but there's no way in hell I'm letting them get away with this.Conceptually, this game is amazing and full of potential. It's the closest thing we have to a Mount and Blade clone. However, with so many years in development and such trivial updates, I've come to realize this will never be a finished, quality product, ESPECIALLY now that it's on special, and it's nothing more than a buggy sandbox with few ways to interact with the world around you. I haven't seen such terrible development constipation since Cortex Command.Please do NOT encourage such dishonest business practices.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I first saw this game, thought it was gonna be a M&B: Warband clone, only in a Asian setting, and that sounded great. But what this game is, is so much more, or at least potentially.You create a character in a post apocalyptic feudal Japan-ish world, and from there your on your own. You can be a merchant, thief, shop owner, start your own town/outpost, craft your own weapons and armor, build different kind of functional buildings, research technology to build/craft even better stuff. You can train in fighting, stealth, repairing etc. by doing what ever you want to train in. Recruit squad members as bodyguards or as part of your personal mercenary group/army and control and train each person individually.At first the game had sub-par GFX (It still not great, but aesthetically pleasing) and no sound, but bear in mind it was still in pre-alpha (currently in alpha), the graphics have improved since, and there is sound now. On top of that new major features keep being added every few months.I bought the game when it was still $10, and it feels like an investment. I play it for a couple of months, when I come back after, say six months, more features are in and feels more polished every time. A few new major features (64bit engine, dialogue, overhauled pathfinding, animals/beasts and a new larger map with biomes) are planned for the near future. They already mentioned the beta in their latest progress update, price will probably go up again. In its current state (28/09/2014) the game is already very enjoyable, so buy it now while it's still in it's alpha pricing $20.PSI only started to play the game on Steam recently, my actual playtime should be more than 100 hours, maybe way more, I don't keep track realy :)

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm writing this for the beta version 0.91.4Now that a small part of the new world map is out I can say that this game is starting to be very fleshed out and there is more land and features to be added (diplomacy being a big one) that will make this even greater game.In the beginning you are weak, unskilled and most often alone. You will be caught stealing or end up pummeled by even lowliest of bandits or beasts. You can even starve to death or be kidnapped by slave traders if you get unlucky. In the worst case you may even end up being eaten alive.If you or whats left of your squad survive you may eventually develop to become strong adventurers, skilled thieves or rich enought traders to hire mercenary squad to protect youself. Eventually you may be able to set up a base of your own where you can farm your own food (if animals don't eat it and you're able to kill them), build walls around it and craft your weapons and armor.I recommend this for anyone interested in a survival game in a fantasy world with added RPG elements.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Within the cesspool of Early access rubbish we get over the recent years, the ugly cash-ins and depressing situations whereby a game is never fully released ever.. Comes this little gem in a desert of emptiness that is Kenshi.Honestly I don't even know where to start. So I shall just wing this. Been playing it for awhile now, a long while and I honestly feel this deserves my personal recommendations to anyone who loves this genre. Let us get down to it, firstly with the cons of the game.1. There's barely any story.Over time, more and more things are added, dialogue bits and now little things here and there, but in a story perspective, it's still very little. Things are getting more fleshed out overtime so we will see things get better in that regard.2. Can still be a bit buggy.It's still early access, things are being added, things get glitchy after being added, balancing still needs some tuning but all is to be expected. Stable version is as expected more stable. (The trespassing of property still needs some work!)2. No multiplayer.This is a single player game, I'm only putting this here for two reasons. One, multiplayer would be quite awesome. Two, I'm lacking of cons to write!Now for the pros of this game.1. Very well done sandbox.It is a sandbox through and through.. You can do almost anything within the game mechanics limitations. You can kill anyone, you can steal from anyone, you can just be a trader, you can essentially be many things or nothing at all! Hell you can even build your own city!2. Combat is straight forward and fun too.Straight forward in the sense you click, and you attack, kind of like diablo without any skills. But your attacks are all sweeps and it's range is dependant on weapon of choice. big♥♥♥♥♥weapon slows you down, slows down your attacks but you hit more people with each swing! Your defense/offense/dodge all grow as you fight more! Your strength grows if you keep carrying heavy stuff! 3. Skills!All your skills grow with more usage! The more you do the same thing the better you are at it in most cases. Though contribuiting factors come into play. Your speed is slowed down by weight, your strength grows by carrying heavy things.. Your offense gets better the more you attack, the defense gets better the more you defend, ectera!4. Choices.A plethora of choices for you to pick, all of which comes around. Do you want to be purely a trader and rely on hired guards? By all means! Do you wanna be a warrior of the lands, heroically killing bandits!? Or become a bandit yourself! All of which requires some kind of sacrifice. A trader sacrifices the money to hire in trade for their safety through the lands. A warrior needs to go through a lot of training to get anywhere decent! And an army of bandits = bad news anyway. In the end you can sort out your group of folks for some to be good at something and others to be good at other things!5. Survival.It is hard, the world is harsh. Wild animals will kill you, bandits will kill you, all of that adds up. But you may not die when you get defeated! You have a blood pool, and every limb has an amount of damage you can take. If you were completely healthy, 90% of the time you don't die, you just pass out. To which you can play dead, or wake up and make a run for it! Just becareful of animals, slavers or cannibals. Animals will nom on you like cannibals. Slavers will enslave you! Training is crucial, so is running! But you can check out the guides for more details! 6. Mods and modding kit!I'm always supportive of mods and modding communities, they make the game different with mods and you can pick whatever mods to suit your game! :DAll in all it's an amazing game that proves there's hope in the industry for something cool to come out! :D

content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
Early Access Review
								One of the best sandbox Squad Based RPG's ever made. I've put over 200+ hours into this game so far and I feel like I'm just getting started!In Kenshi, you start out by yourself or with a few others (depending on your game start), hungry, and alone in one of the largest hand crafted game worlds I've ever seen. Your first priority is to find food. Steal it, hunt for it, or trade for it. Encounter a vast population of creatures some of which are docile, and others who are aggressive and will eat you! With currently over 30 factions some larger than others, all who have their own personalities and goals. The Holy Nation hates any non-human race. Be prepared to fight their enslavement if you are of another race in their territory. Travel to the swamplands, and find yourself battling Swamp Ninjas, and other factions fighting to control the area. Travel to the far south, and encounter mercenaries that will rough you up if you don't pay them.Hire new companions, equip them with weapons and armor, and train their fighting skills to survive in this world.Become a slaver. Capture enemies, and sell them as slaves. Slavers will slave you if they find you knocked out, and you are forced into slavery until you escape.Become a warrior/ninja, conquer all who oppose you or die in the attempt.Become a bounty hunter, and find bounties worth a lot of money and bring them to justice.Become a thief, and steal from everyone. Get caught stealing, and get thrown in prison. Escape prison, and become wanted. Fight off bounty hunters that will eventually hunt for you.Become a farmer, and sell produce, or illegal goods to other factions. Get caught smuggling into a city and you'll go to jail.Build multiple bases anywhere! Choose from a large amount of buildings, do research to build new buildings and items. Craft your own weapons and armor. Create high walls with turrets to protect your base from attacks from rival factions.Or:You can do all of the things I listed in the same game. You can do whatever you want, but be prepared for the consequences!Kenshi is truely a unique, and remarkable game that deserves your money.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is a massivly open world RTS/RPG hybrid that brings to the RTS genre what I've always wanted to have.  I have been following the progress of this game for a long time now and I can tell you the developer is not giving up on this game.  In fact, the game has grown from beiing produced by a one man team for the first 6 or more years (Chris The Great A.K.A. Captian Deathbeard) to a full fledged indie studio.  Progress has picked up a lot recently with the new AI, Creatures, and a new World Map 4X bigger than the current one (which is massive already) with much much  more than just the desert and mountains biomes we have now.  Each character in your crew levels up differently, has their own inventory and skill levels and can be fully controlled seprately.  You can fight stuff, start a village, mine things, research new buildings and things to put in buildings, keep training your men (or an awesome team of Charlie's Angle style girls with a mysterious leader who they've never seen like I did).  Your village can grow into a massive city through tons and tons and tons and tons and tons and tons of work, but it's all worth it in the end.  Have a lone solider or command an army of unstoppable awesomeness (or sexiness).  Don't let the low number of hours fool you, I must have had over 100 hours on the pre-steam alpha release.  I haven't been playing it too much lately mostly because I'm going to do a brand new start when the new massivly updated map comes into beta in the summer, and the fact that there is currently an annoying random crash bug that happens when wandering far distances, so keep hitting F5 to autosave every few minutes.  Those things aside, this game is definately worth $20 and I suggest you get it now because I have a feeling when the new map comes out this summer, the price might raise to $25-$30.  I got it when it was $10 and it was the best 10 bucks I've ever spent online.   Just remember to have patience, and death is permanent.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great for those that enjoy a true sandbox RPG with plenty of swordfighting and a large amount of city-building available.Updating this review now that I have more time dedicated to write it.This is going to be a very patchwork comparison of Kenshi to other games that a potential buyer may, or may not, already own, and I will detail my personal experiences for you all to read, or not. :DSo, Kenshi is a squad-based RPG (think of Dawn of War 2, but each individual character in the squad has their own D&D-style character sheet) with some RTS elements (specifically the capability of building structures and researching technologies to unlock new structures, items, and upgrades) that puts a strong emphasis on open-ended gameplay (many puns to be had playing a sandbox game set in the desert).The Kenshi-verse (name of the world chosen by several members of the community, including myself) is an original creation with influences from the Edo Period in Japan (weapons and armor models are influenced by the samurai of that time, and it has been confirmed there will be no weapons relying on gunpowder or later technologies, just pure swordplay with some ranged combat and unarmed combat to come in the future).You, as a new player, get to choose from one of multiple starting points (i.e. a trader, retired soldier, etc.), and each starting point essentially grants the player a specific character(s) that have certain advantages and disadvantages.Keep in mind that there is a very strong emphasis on open-ended gameplay, so any of these starting points can be molded and shaped to create the character(s) that you will enjoy most.Regardless of the starting point chosen, your character will start at, or close to, rock bottom with little more than a rusty blade and the clothes on your back.The point of this is that your character(s) will grow and gain experience in the numerous skills and attributes (the # of skills and attributes currently available (17) appear to be about half of what is planned for the final release) by performing activities that are related to that skill.Things such as carrying a heavy load or swinging a heavy weapon in combat will improve your Strength, whereas wielding a lighter weapon will increase Dexterity.Even at the farm, crafting weapons/armor, picking locks, or simply running laps around town will increase their corresponding skills (btw, each of these actions I listed apply to unique skills).Once your starting point is chosen, you are then introduced to a rather in-depth character creation screen.This character creation screen allows you to choose either gender as well as modify hair, eyes, skin, muscle tone, height, weight, girth, bust, and most importantly, facial hair.After creating your character, it is possible to find an NPC called the Plastic Sugeon (should be at least 1 in every NPC town) that will allow you to modify any character in your squad using this character creation screen (it goes without saying this emphasizes the sandbox part even more).After you're satisfied with your character, then explore the Kenshi-verse to your heart's content!I say this because the current world (which is nothing but desert) has been confirmed to be less than 1/4 of the actual Kenshi-verse, AND this new world map is currently in the works as I am typing this.Some basic control shortcuts to help new players get started:Shift+LMB stack of multiple items = Allows player to pick up whole stacks of itemsHold RMB over any character = Brings up a list of all the actions that can be performed on this character (NPC or PC)The rest of the basic controls are either given to you at the start of gameplay or can be found, and rebound, in the Options -> Controls menu.Another HUGE part of Kenshi that I haven't even touched yet is modding.Kenshi has been developed from its core to allow extensive modding so that each player can have an even more unique experience.To my knowledge, there are mods available that:Add new weapons/armor to the Kenshi-verseAdd dialogue, and dialogue trees, to NPCs (which bring a large variety of things from quests to mercenaries, and I think its also possible to edit existing dialogue to read in other languages)Add structures to Kenshi and modify their functional components (things such as a structure's capability to receive an item to Input and produce an Output from it or to allow the mass Storage of a certain item)Modify components of NPCs in various ways (things such as # of bandits in each squad, add entire NPC towns, change ownership of an existing town from one faction to another)Among many, many other mods that have already been produced by the Kenshi community.There are also numerous, well-detailed tutorials available for any user to learn how to mod Kenshi in less than a day's worth of time.Anyone that has read this far should go to:www.lofigames.comand check out all of the information available there.Be sure to click on the Roadmap tab at the top to see everything that is planned and when it will be implemented.Oh, and you should totally join in the conversations on the Forums (I'm on there a lot ;D).Chris, THE dev and programmer of Kenshi, also posts regular updates to his twitter page as well as screenshots at:www.twitter.com/lofigames

content:
Posted: April 4
Early Access Review
								As much as I want to like this game, after so many years in development and the current state it's in I'm done hoping. The idea is great and the style is there, but that's where it's ended and stayed practically from the get-go.Let's face it - Kenshi has been in development for about 10 years now and it's still riddled with issues. Crashes, poor UI, lack of versatility (can't even change font size), and instead of working on these basic issues the devs re-design the entire map, which is arguably no better than the original. I know the dev team is tiny, if not just one person, and they are consistently working on the game, but after such a long time in development I was hoping to see some polish. Instead it feels just like when I first bought it.Suggestion to the dev(s) - I'm sure the money must be drying up now and this suggestion is probably very late, but money makes money and you have to invest to do business. Hire someone else that's good at what you're not, or you are never going to finish this game.

Posted: November 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Look, you either like open-ended, experimental sandbox games or you don't. If you do, you'll be able to look past this game's bugs and its current lack of content. If you don't, stop reading and go back to COD. Contrary to what some other reviewers are saying, this game is updated regularly, but you might have to opt in to the unstable build to see it. They've also been working on an entirely new world map which is due out soon. Over the past year they've added animals, slavery, formations, a new race, and many other systems and features, not to mention improving the pathfinding dramatically. The game is very different from when I purchased it a couple years ago and I think it shows a ton of promise.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								So.. Kenshi.I've been following this game for a while now that I completely forgot that it existed and also forgot how long I've been waiting on this game.I remember a time when the game was bugged when your desert turned into grass for some odd reason, weirdly deformed bodies using the character editor, green American football-looking gear as armor and even using building blueprints as walls because walls didn't exist.So how is it now? Amazing. This game now looks bloody amazing when I had a look, the desert looks a lot like a proper desert now. There's better buildings to construct, its got better stability and less bugs. You can steal, build proper fortresses, hire many more squad members into your empire. Heck, there are even animals in the game added in.The gameplay itself is.. A little bit repetitive(Note: only a little). You charge a bandit down, watch the fight, get absolutely smashed, get back up again, then charge a different bandit until you get strong enough to beat them down. However, this is not the whole game. In Kenshi, there are quests to do, stuff to loot, civilians to save from cannibals, cities to pillage, robbing dying people in the desert then patching them up etc. There's plenty of things to do, you just have to decide which ones you want to do. It's free-roam after all.Now this game isn't complete yet and even if it is has less bugs that doesn't mean it doesn't exist but it at least means there's still progress within the game. The developers take their time in this and I admire them for taking it slow, albeit a bit too slow. But the fact that I still see progress in 4? 6 years? is simply a testament to the love they have for the game and developing a game itself.Seriously, thank you, for being one of the Early access games that I've bought and still not abandoned after all this time.P.S. I voted this for the 'I thought this game was cool before it won an award' award on this. Partly, the reason why I made a review just now. :P

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Where to start. I can honestly say Kenshi is an addiction for me. It just keeps pulling me back in. The devs have taken the effort to keep this game user firendly all through the development and updates by providing an import feature. Even with the addition of the new world I was able to import and to this day I am still running the same squad I started with countless moons ago.Yes, it is early access.Yes there have been times where It has been very frustrating because I need my Kenshi fix but the latest patch crashes on game start. ( usually fixed very quickly and often even on weekends)Yes the optimization is pretty poor depeneding on the in game viewpoint. (Top down view runs fairly smooth on my rig while traveling across the map)Yes there are issues that come and go regarding AI pathing and implementation of the crafting tasks.BUTIs there anything I just mentioned that you wouldn't expect from an Early Access game?The devs always keep a stable branch available that you can play if the experimental branch is too annoying for your tastes.The modders have done a fantastic job of filling in with content that that hasn't been implemented or has changed, sometimes not for the better during  development.it IS difficult and testing of your faith in the beginning. There is no hand holding and your character is no born hero. Just a lowly Joe and everyone will hurt you. But that's the hook. As your character begins to grow and learn there is great satisfaction when you take down the first bully and take all his s**t for your personal use.Satisfaction building your first outpost building.Satisfaction when your researcher discovers a new technology.Satisfaction when your armorsmith or weaponsmith finally creates a noteworthy item.Satisfaction when you complete the last wall and lock your base gate feelling you have created a secure home for your squad.I say this because none of it will come easy and after all of the hours invested you begin to care for your squad. They have worked to become something possibly great and when they get hurt there is a real feeling of anxiety when a member is on the verge of death, laying unconcious and being eaten alive by cannibals or local wildlife.It has been a long drawn out process and the development still continues. There is no story, you become what you choose. Befriend factions, make enemies with entire factions, your choice.If you like long term gameplay (like Eve online) where there is no quick win and you  take pride in what you can achieve over many, many hours then I say by all means it's worth every penny.  If you have no patience and are easily pushed to rage quit, then please purchase to support the devs for ME! and play something else. hahaGood Luck in the world of Kenshi

content:
Posted: January 16
Early Access Review
								This is probably one of the most unique games on steam because of the endless choices given to the player and the amount of reward and punishment that come with each choice, I'll give a few examples:-If you decide to hone your combat skills choose carefully who you pick your fights with, the stronger your oponent is the faster you will gain on skill, infact losing the fight will make you tougher and stronger than winning it, but this is not always the smarter choice since the world is filled with cannibals, slavers and monsters that prey on laying bodies, so getting knocked out sometimes means you will lose more than the fight (kidnapped,chained,sold off, eaten alive, etc).-If you decide to settle down and build a base learn who and what roams around the territory where you build, you might get harassed by racist/sexist factions who want to take your non-human and female workers as slaves and will raid you if you don't cooperate, or you might have bandits and monsters trashing your gates and slaughtering your workers and farms constantly. (this made me rage quit a few times, but it is so rewarding when you finally get to stand on your own and hunt down all these mother***ers.)-If you become a trader and make enough cats(ingame currency name) you can hire really powerful mercenaries to act as bodyguards to keep your business clean, and have a slave serve you some homemade sake and rum at the commodity of your tower while someone else run your bar, shop, armory or whatever business you own.-If you just want to live as an adventurer and explore the world you might find hidden ruins with unique treasures and weapons that sell for insane prices or an outpost at the ends of the world owned by some most wanted criminal that has an outrageous bounty on his head.The list goes on but is hard to describe everything you can do in this game because it is almost up to your imagination, mechanic-wise it has few limitations. I started the game in 2013-14ish but it became unplayable because of the constant crashes, now that the crashing and most of the bugs are gone the game it's starting to show it's true potential,  if you are a fan of this type of game you are missing on a lot even though it's still on beta. The game has a steep learning curve, I recommed watching some of the recent tutorials and gameplay videos on youtube because those on steam are outdated and don't even show half of the things you can do in the game mechanic-wise.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								0.92 version patched ---the current versionKenshi is a different kind of game. It's a a squad based survival type game in a different land. Players can start in different game options but the main idea is to aquire other squad mates ( 30 Max. More with mods ), train is skills, research new technologies, build bases, farms, ore processors *er* processers, make weapons, armor, clothing....etc. You can even build booths for NPC's to buy your stuff. And of course new technologies mean new buildings and things to make. All the while, their are various factions that are either neutral to you or are trying to kill you. Combat is realtime with small battles up to huge armies (well like hundreds * w/ mods*). Various body parts can become injured and it will have a real effect ie. leg badly damaged? your character limps..arm nearly cut off? it dangles on your body. Your characters will lose conciousness before dying and depending on the severity of the wounds may just bleed out. However someone may heal you or pick up your unconcious body. This may be a bad thing. See, there are slavers and cannibals. If slavers capture you, you'll be hauled off to the nearest city and put in a cage, or forced to join another groups faction (as a slave). If cannibals capture, you will also be put in a cage...but they plan on eating you. Its not game over here in either scenario as you may be able to pick the lock and sneak out of the cage and make a run for it. Better find some food though, your characters can and will starve. A neat graphic here is if your character starts to starve...you will start to see the physical effects on them...ie ribs start showing, arms and legs start to get skinny...Now keep in mind you may have many characters, so if one gets hauled off to a slave camp, your other characters can go free him. Also characters can be assigned jobs, which the AI handles quite Nicely. A farmer may plow a field put the farmed material (there are several things you can grow) in a container, obtain water from a well, water the crops, and resume farming if there are still plants to be reaped. And thats just one job. Impressed? Thats not even close to all you can do in Kenshi.As read my review I realize I sound like a DEV of the game. I can assure you I most certainly am not. I am not exaggerating one iota about the tons of stuff you can do.Note: Kenshi has been in development for a long, long time. I have had this game for over 2 years. Things didn't always work right. Because of this there are some bad reviews. But I encourage anyone who played in the past to pick up on it again. Gone is that slow laggy game, replaced with a smooth as silk gaming experience. Still lags when changing regions though.The one negative comment I have is there is no verbal dialogue. It's not terrible or anything but it makes the world kinda flat. Now I'm 50 years old so of course I've played tons of great games with no dialogue. It's just a wish of mine to enhance the world. Also quest would be nice, but I LOVE sandbox games.I STRONGLY reccomend this game. It's really fun and different and coming together nicely now. For me 9/10.So thats it. I'm going back to the land of Kenshi now.....Cheers all

Early Access Review
								I've been waiting on this game to become playable for like 4 years now. The developer obviously has never had any clear direction in mind for this game. It's just a case of throwing random♥♥♥♥♥♥together into one hideous abomination. There is no consistency to anything in this game. None of the features feel like they work well together. You start the game and immediately ask yourself "Okay, what is there to do?" I still don't have an answer for that. Build a house I guess? But why bother? Get money maybe? Oh that way I can get that one expensive sword at the shop. To do what with? Oh, kill the same old bandits you've been seeing right from the start that use the same old rusty pieces of♥♥♥♥♥♥swords.Kenshi never progressed from feeling like a tech demo into feeling like an actual game. There is no feeling of progression in this game. There are no goals that feel worth working towards. None of it is satisfying. There's no point to anything. This is not a sandbox game, it is a tech demo at best.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Allow me to say this: If you do NOT have a large amount of patience, this game is not for you, at least not yet.Kenshi is a wonderful game, I've sunk days and days of my time into this Early Access, and I love it. The feeling of being horribly puny in a world that seeks to better itself , and then becoming strong enough to crush the world is a feeling only comparable to doing the same thing in your everyday life. That is Kenshi. You write your story, you act it out. Crush your opposition, or bankrupt their pocketbooks? Annihalate the bandits, or help them take over cities? You are, or will, be asked these questions over and over.Another of the great things about Kenshi is that it takes the motto of Urbanprophet; Unfair, Random, Brutality; and takes it to the next level. The game is exceedingly Unfair. You will probably lose men. That one-man army you really want to be? Well, he's lying on the ground, dying slowly after being attacked by 30 bandits. It's a painfully wonderful experience. It is Brutal, the enemies do not go easy on you- You just killed those Samurai's buddies? The entire faction wants you dead now, and you have armies of some of the strongest people in the game after you. Oh, now you can watch your 12 man squad rot slowly on the dusty desert. It is Random. No two people are the same unless they're twins or you made them that way. Every combat experience is utterly random. Yes, there's SOME consistency, as a soldier with 40 combat skill and 40 Defense skill probably won't get taken out by a couple of hungry bandits, but lucky hits DO happen. It can be frustrating to see that up-armored beast get KO'd by some thugs with sticks, but even SAS Operatives get shot by untrained Guerillas. You almost have to be a masochist to play Kenshi. Almost.Unfortunately, the game is consistently buggy, whether it be from minor graphics glitches caused by saving/loading, upto pathing issues that can be game-breaking. It's painful to be forced to watch your men die on the sands, and the fact that the game can't recognize your men are all pretty much dead and allow you to start a new game is a little offensive. The lack of a "Return to Main Menu" button is a little disconcerting in itself.In addition to that, it lacks a lot of diversity in its content. The "Music" is virtually nonexistent. It almost makes it difficult to want to play the game. Almost. Weaponry and Armor for your characters has a distinctly Asian flair, but doesn't deviate far from that. Combat animations are virtually the same for all people and weapons, and Melee combat is currently all there is. You buy Mercenaries. You kill things. You might even build a base. It's easy to become disillusioned if you aren't patient, or a good role-player.At the moment, the one game I can compare this to is a 3D Version of Caravaneer, without guns, and that is a very good thing. What the developer here tries to pull off is an extensive trade network with fluctuating prices; towns that have surplus stocks and will pay desperately with whatever they can to get what they're on a shortage of. That doesn't happen.Despite all of its flaws, Kenshi is a masterpiece. While dated in its mission, lacking in content, and occasionally utterly monotonous, Kenshi delivers the ultimate RPG experience that even real life cannot give you: The chance to write your own story, completely unfettered by society. The only problem you have left to figure out is: Do you cut your path into the ground, do you line it with the ruins of empires, do you gild it with coin, or do you merely walk it? It's upto you to write the story; it's upto you to buy and play Kenshi.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is a refreshing, challenging, and unique sandbox game where there is no main story, no main character, and certainly no friends. That is, unless you make those things happen. But to create that story blood, sweat, and tears must be shed for the bustling town that you build from the ground up or the greatest warriors the land has ever seen to be created. The first few hours of this game are hard, very, very hard. You typically start off with rough spun pants, a medkit, a few hundred Cats (the currency), and a stick in a city within the wasteland. And off you go. No tutorial, no hand holding, no direction as to what you should or can do. There are certainly in-game Help menus you could look through, but you yourself have to discover how to make money for food, where you should avoid going, and how best to survive in a wasteland where you're nothing more than another grain of sand in the dessert, just as easily treaded over, discarded, and forgotten. You can't even kill a lone animal, much less another person, for survival. At least initially. Kenshi is a game where stories, your stories, are made. There are no scripted events, no unkillable NPC's, and plenty of random events that you encounter travelling the wasteland for adventures to happen. I left my base once to explore, found a ruin, almost got killed in it, half my squad limping away carrying the other half of my unconscious, but alive, team. Limping home through a forest before Bam! I got attacked by twenty or so cannibals and somehow, by some miracle, held them off with my wounded, conscious members. The moment when the walls of my base rendered on my screen was filled with so much joy, relief, and amazement that everyone somehow made it back alive still makes me shake my head in disbelief that a game made me experience that.This game is all about growth and development, discovery and adventure, survival and death. It does a remarkable job of invoking the doubts involved with exploring the unknown. Everytime I send out an expedition with enough food and supplies to last a week or more to bring back new trade items or rare treasure I worry whether or not everyone, or anyone at all for that matter, will make it back alive. I don't know what I'll find, what I'll encounter, and if the journey will be worth it. And that's an incredible feeling.This game is still being developed and still has tons of things to improve, but what they have now is a fun, albeit challenging and buggy, squad based, sandbox game where it's you and the world. Is Kenshi, an Eary Access game, worth the $20? Having played almost 52 fun, stressful, amazing hours at the moment of writing I'm very much inclined to say yes, absolutely. A good chunk of time has to be invested to actually experience everything Kenshi currently has to offer and considering that the game isn't even complete yet pleases me, knowing that there's that much more for me to discover.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								If Mad Max, Samurai Champloo, and The Dark Tower had a weird kid that ran around shirtless with nothing but a rusty katana and an empty stomach, then it would be this game.The setting is unique, taking place in a varied post-apocalyptic enviroment that's soon to be expanded with a shiny new map. Combat is dangerous and every encounter has the potential to be your last. Numerous factions have their wars and alliances, and you can participate if you want, or just loot the corpses like a gross human vulture that has no honor.The problem with the games are thus: The engine isn't the best in the world, so graphically it's rather unimpressive, however the artists have done a great job with worldbuilding and locations look unique enough that graphical limitations don't hinder the game at all. Another possible gripe is that the early game's combat is very, very hard. You will be knocked out for most of your time with Kenshi without proper preperation. It's stupid to brave the wasteland alone, you aren't the Dragonborn; you're Jeff from accounting who's decided to become a vagrant warrior with little to know chance of survival. That being said, a larger party and training vis a vie the practice dummies can make combat easier.All in all Kenshi has been developed slowly over a long period of time, and it's clear the developers have put love into their game. Updates are progressing steadily and adding in new content and features. Kenshi's a good game now, but it'll be a great game when it gets released.

Early Access Review
								I don't write reviews, infact this is the only one i've done or probably will do because this is my favorite game on steam.Pros:-The ability to customize units is what sold me on this. I've always loved being able to make my own stories and characters within a game and it works well in this.-There is always a new story to tell with your character(s). If you do some research you can see the guy who made this game loves it and truely wants to see it finished (even hired more people to help build it).Cons:-Like I said, the updates can take a long time to come out but they do.-Some people experience bugs and crashes while others do not.-Once you get your characters up to a certain level in combat it may become a little too easy. However, they are adding new stuff to keep it challenging.If you enjoy these games you may enjoy this one:X-com, Age of Empires, Mount and bladeOver-all I give this game a 8.5/10 in the experimental beta build. Like a fine wine, it gets better with time.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								It was " 29 Oct, 2013 @ 12:07pm " when I created my review on the game, I praised it with such adoration but times change and thanks to the sales it has been brought to my attention. My first question is; why hasn't this game been completed yet? I shall now answer my own question with: it is because of you, the loyal customer, only you the ones who have been active in the forum have interfered with this game being completed the way it was intended. How? You ask? People like to demand that the developers include everything under the sun they desire, pointless trivial things such as 'race' and I recall someone mentioned 'hot-air balloons' and so on and so forth. Let us all remind ourselves that this is a post-apocalyptic world that thrives because of its realism, now then, I've had this game since it came out and I am certain this game was never supposed to go down the road of 'races' and the mystical such. If you are angry that this game is not complete like I am, it is because of said developers not having a clear focus and an active forum. Now I am not saying it is a bad thing that the developers are allowing their customers to influence the game I mean, we paid for it, we should be allowed to have a say, yes that is good practice but what annoys me is when the game starts to spin off into a half complete spiral of forever being at 50% because people keep asking for 'cool' stuff and as a result unforseen bugs occur that require manhours to fix which all builds up and here we are. Now they have added cannibals, and I think great, something to keep the player focused on their...well, squad I guess, this might have been a player-suggested idea although from the general feel of the game when I had first made my review I could have predicted a group as such existing. My only main issue, is that the game often finds itself struggling to balance the micro-management aspect and the combat aspect of the game, for example, at the beginning of the game, you are by your own (assuming you picked either the merchant or the default spawn), you have to survive and learn, you lure some bandits into a city they get violently murdered and you sell their stuff, get some more squad members, rinse and repeat, it's great fun, I'm sure each player would agree. THEN we are tempted into creating our own city.The city building is a fun aspect but it simply becomes a process of just sitting on your♥♥♥♥♥♥staring into nothing watching your members work away for hours on end until you travel back to sell your wares, remember that there are bandits, end up having to sacrifice a slower member for the 'greater good' and then get back into the combat aspect, bored of base building. All-in-all I'd still actually suggest that you buy this game but just don't expect too much clarity in where this game will end up.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								In 2016 I can safely say that abandoned games get updated at a faster rate. You know those games that sound very, very good? Kenshi is one of those games. Unfortunately, Kenshi has sounded very good for a long time now and hasn't actually had much added to it. You'll spend most of your time watching a character walk from place to place while keeping the game on fast forward. But perhaps the combat is redeeming, you say? Nope, you fast forward that too. In fact, there's very little reason to not just play this game on fast forward the entire time. It's basically a watching simulator. But the fun doesn't end there. The forums are rather heavily censored and anything that isn't praise toward the developers is deleted and followed by a ban. As of now, I don't think people who don't own kenshi can even post there. This is clearly just an attempt to censor the forum more heavily.So, why should you consider kenshi? Well, if you like games that have been in development for years with minimal progress it's right up your alley! If you like games where you hit an endgame with almost nothing to do it's perfect as well!And if you go to the forum for tips you'll be told to "make your own game(Within kenshi)." Yup, the consistent suggestion on the forum is to make your own little game, with your own rules and a load of artificial difficulty that you impose on yourself.  The reason for this is, of course, that there's absolutely nothing else to do. You make a little base, get a few guys, and that is it. That is completion of the game. It's not even a matter of ignoring a bunch of features. That is all the features right now(and has been for a very long time).

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Yes.As of this current day (2nd of March, 2017), I can honestly say Kenshi is worth it, after a long period of "not quite there yet". But for the love of everything that is good and decent, INSTALL THIS GAME TO AN SSD! Seriously! The loading times and the general performance are still awful!I've been game since the 0.2x alpha, can't exactly remember which exact version, but it was the one before the first foliage update. Back then, the game was pretty barebones. All you could do was to wander around beating bandits or the members of bigger factions up, until your character became a god of war. The game had so much potential, but little to do in terms of diversity. The game also crashed constantly, the pathfinding was abysmal and everything was generally clunky and frustrating, so I couldn't really recommend the game.Now, the performance is still crap, the pathfinding is still occasionally annoying (although much more tolerable than what it used to be) and everything is still quite clunky. But the game has so much to offer, it packs in so many great details, and it's all-around a completely unique experience!Kenshi is an RTS sandbox, with relatively heavy emphasis on RPG elements, one which absolutely doesn't hold your hand with pillow-padded tutorials and scaling levels of enemies. It drops you to a cold, incredibly merciless and unforgiving world, where your survival, a pathetic little weakling that you are, is tough! You need food, you need weapons, you need armor, you need a MUCH higher skills to do anything, you need allies... even the lowliest of bandits will beat your starting character with ease, and don't except any kind of one-on-one action, as these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s will outnumber you ten-to-one! And when they beat you senseless, they take loot your body and take your precious food - and that's the best case scenario! If your opponent happens to be a fogman, a cannibal or a wild animal, it will probably eat you as well!But the beauty of Kenshi isn't just the magnificently cruel, beautifully crafted game world with tons of places to explore and millions of incredible little details that no other game offers, it's when you FINALLY make it! When you finally recover from the beatdown, when you finally rebuild yourself stronger, when you finally get back to those #¤%&/! bandits and shove their rusty sticks down their throats, when you finally save your tortured comrades from slavery, when you finally have a place of your own, when you finally make your base self-sufficient... that's when the game feels like an accomplishment! This trick is hard to pull off by a game, but Kenshi absolutely nails it.Unfortunately, the game isn't without its flaws. The unforgiving nature of the game can be a turn-off to some people, so if you expect a relaxing base-building game, look elsewhere. As mentioned before, the game absolutely requires an SSD at its current state, or else you can expect hideously long loading times ALL THE TIME. Some UI elements, as the game mechanisms in general, are incredibly clunky and probably will always be. But if you can look past its flaws, Kenshi is an incredible experience, one which I can definitely recommend! :)

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR:It's a true to the word Alpha so it crashes and there are clearly parts of the game that do not work yet. However, the greater vision for what the game will be is clear and it clearly is going to be a game of epic proportions with plenty of replayability.Full Review:The game lets you play as you wish. Want to be a BA swordsman with an elite squad of goons? Done. Want to be tader making your way through the waste lands? Done. Want to settle your own town and be the greatest blacksmith in the land? Done. Want to by a sleezy tief in the night? Done.The game has a fantastic engine that allows you level your character based on the actions he takes. If you fight a lot, he will become better at fighting. If you run around a lot he becomes a faster runner. Carry heavy things - builds strength. Unit growth is very organic, though you can also setup tasks to help power level guys as well.The main game, which is not completed yet, will allow you to effectively build your own clan. You will be able to raid other towns and even take them over. If you do not want to run your own clan with towns then you can try your hand at being a merchinary in one of the many conflicts that will going on around the map.The game is also introducing multiple races and ambient creatures that will kick your butt!!All the fun stuff aside there are some drawbacks. At the time of the post this is still very much in Alpha. The game crashes regularly, your save files become outdated or unable to be retrieved often, and your are constantly tantilzed by the features you can see but not use. For an Alpha it is pretty playable though and the dev makes balancing changes every so often so that the game remains fun to play.If you cannot handle losing your entire saved game or getting randomly kicked this is not the time to buy, wait for the proper release. If you can't wait to be a steampunk samuri in a desert wasteland then by all means get it!

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is roughly how it went for me. The first 10 hours I was just running away from things and reloading, cursing at the game and wondering how you were supposed to play this if you just got jumped all the time. The next 10 hours was spent discovering things, some on my own and some from searching. I got a small group of people together and saved up several thousand working resource nodes outside the cities. Whenever I had to travel though I was just running away from things and reloading, cursing at the game and wondering how you were supposed to play this if you just got jumped all the time.Then I started to get my bearings in the game. I learned that losing is part of the experience, literally part of the experience. If you pick an even fight and don't come out on top, you've still gained big defensive stats on anyone that didn't die. At that point, about 30 hours deep into the experience, I realized I just started. Game mechanics start springing up and spider-webbing outward. Character advancement, technology research, crafting, settlement management, supply runs, training, assaults, battles, wars. Now every time I assemble my elite crew of four to the gate, I get excited that I have so many options to choose from. We go to a city, make some money, recruit more people for the town, work their strength up a little to make some more money nearby, buy some supplies and sneak them back up.The game creeps up on you and owns you with complex, interesting things to do. The mechanics, dialog, options and behavior of npcs are deep and seem very well thought out. I often find myself doing something I fully expect to result in losing something and figure out the game already thought of it and provided an option. And if you're worried there may not be enough RPG in it for you, each and every character you recruit is playable, equippable and trainable independently. The vanilla cap is I think 30 right now total recruitable, but there is a mod already that increases it to 256. Give it some time and you'll be hooked.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kenshi, holy ♥♥♥♥, where do I start with this one? Hmmm, how about my experience on my first proper playthrough(s).....I started with a new playthrough after re-installing this game yesterday, as the default wanderer. All was well, at first. I spawned in Blister Hill. I mined some iron, sold the iron to a trader in Blister Hill and got a fair amount of money doing so. I built a small outpost with a shack, farm and a well down near the river, just outside of Blsiter Hill. My crops were growing fine, I had a fair bit of money but I needed some materials, so I mined more iron and made more money in the easiest way I knew how, MINING!!! After I arrived back from Blister Hill I noticed all my crops had dissappeared, "what?" I thought to myself, "How?" I originally thought the starving bandits had knocked me over, so I replanted my crops, mined more iron, sold more iron in Blister Hill and after arriving back for the second time....my crops where missing, again. So I re-replanted them, headed to the Holy Farm to get some stuff, come back and my crops had gone AGAIN. At this point I was just baffled, "a glitch maybe?" I re-re-replanted my crops, waited in my shack and nothing.....then I see my character yell out "BY OKRANS HAIRY NIPPLES" he draws out his sword and sprints out of the shack, I pan the camera and a dozen of these rat creatures with 2 legs are eating my ♥♥♥♥ing crops. "No match for me" I thought, wow how I was wrong. I get completley destroyed and killed by these creatures. RIP Zan.Second playthrough, this time as a trader with a pack bull, seems fun! I spawn in some remote area with a few buildings dotted around the place, I decide to head to Blister Hill and sell my luxury goods that I spwaned with. Less than 5 minutes in, I get ambushed by cannibals, my bull gets killed and I get kidnapped. Then, the cannibal just stops walking, glitches and I am stuck like this for around 10 minutes, dying on this skinny cannibals shoulder. "♥♥♥♥ sake, new game it is...again"RIP Bill.Third playthrough, this time as the retired army captain, ♥♥♥♥ yeah dude. I chose him due to my 2 previous characters being absolutley dreadful when it comes to combat. I spawn in The Hub, a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ full of low-lives and outlaws, I find an iron vein, so I repeat the mining method in order to get some money. I have 5 raw iron ore, I see a building just outside of The Hub, I walk in, sell my iron and buy a nice sword to go with my other one, I step out of the building and BAM, badnits do me over and loot my weapons......"This game is a ♥♥♥♥ing joke" I shout out loud. Fortunatley, I recover and the traders kill the bandits, unfortuntaley the one who robbed me, took off with my swords. I loot an iron club off one of the bandits, buy some food and set off. I approach a hive village, BAM. Ambushed by cannibals and kidnapped again....."Wow, what the ♥♥♥♥!?!!?" I exclaim, fortunatley I am saved by these bug looking ant men, who are actually rather nice! I set up camp outside of the hive village, mine some copper, sell to the trader, make some more money and set off to greener pastures. BAM, ambushed by fogmen, kidnapped and hauled around the fog islands for about 20 minutes until cannibals attack and kill my kidnappers. I play dead, then immediatley run for the hills. I run into a cannibal, who is not attacking me. "Talking meat?" he says, I ask him not to eat me due to my body being diseased with plague "STILL HAVE TO EAT" he yells back at me, BAM, his posse attack me, kidnap me and again I am hauled around the map, knocked out cold, then, starving bandits save me! "OMG Saved again, thank ♥♥♥♥" I say to myself......no, the bandits then knock me out, steal my food and take off. I wake up from a recovery coma, heal myself then limp off toward Mongrel, A town located in the fog islands. I arrive, and to make more money, I mine a nearby iron source. I go to the weapons trader with my recently aqquired iron, "OHHH a smithing machine, I'll make armour plates and get♥♥♥♥♥♥loads of money" I work on the armour plates in the shop, then I take my armour plate, a message pops up "Caught stealing" I get attacked by 20+ guards and arrested for taking an armour plate that I MADE....."♥♥♥♥. THIS. GAME."Kenshi is a nightmare, its harder than life, harder than dark souls, but it's actually fun to play. You arent a god, you are a weak, feeble character looking to make a name for themselves, and man it is hard. The graphics are bad, the performance is awful at times due to poor omptimization but the gameplay and replayability of this game is outstanding. The world, that seems to be a mix of Japanese culture mixed in with some steam/cyber-punk aspects, has an interesting story with weird characters inhabiting it, what a strange yet good game Kenshi is.I hated this game at first, which is why I ultimatley uninstalled it a few months back. The game just needs time for you to grow attatched to it, which bizzarely, will happen.
