content:
Posted: February 15
Early Access Review
								This game is great if you have a big imagination.  There is no story, and there never will be.  Quests do not exist, but the developers are working on a job system which will give your characters some short-term direction; these "non-quests" will not advance a plot.  The map is large, some complain that it is too large, and there is enough explore.  The game is close to release and they've scrapped about 1/2 of the features that were listed back in 2013-2014 when I added this game to my wishlist.  The current experimental version is 95.14, full release is at 1.0.  I'm not sure what else they will drop before they release the "final version," they have scrapped so much that the developers have stated that they "may" release a post final version patch which will add some of the cancelled features; but it seems more like they are eager to put this project behind them.Despite my concerns, I really like this game as it stands.  The premise is this right now: you start out with a character.  The character is weak.  Over time they develop their skills (combat, crafting, labor).  Eventually they're not weak anymore.  You can have up to 30 of these characters.  You can built a base, craft, trade, etc.  Since the game has no goals, the thought behind play ends up being.  It would be cool if I ..., or I want to have the best .... There are several factions scattered throughout the map with their own culture.  On final release you should be allowed to ally, and war with whoever you choose.As with any early access game: only time will tell what makes it into the final version.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Honestly a very good and promising Early Access title. I'll tell you my story so far...It started off with just me and my dog. At the beggining things were tough, I was starving and only had 13 cats (Money) to my name, I've been begging in this little farm community for quite some time now, but the people have stopped just giving me food. I had no other choice, I started mining with the local populace to sell at the nearby market to get some food for myself and my dog. After about 10 days of selling iron ore I bought my first Bison and a bag to go on it's back. Now I started venturing further to the cities around the farm selling minerals to barely scrape by. I saved up some funds and bought some building materials to build my very own shack, nothing amazing and quite small, but it's the first roof i've had for a long time so i'm not complaining. After sleeping the night and eating some dried meat i built a well and a vegetable farm, along with a wheat field. Things were finally looking up.  The only problem now is that it's just me to defend against the local wildlife that pillages my fields of vegetables. Some days I spend the whole day inside just so the animals don't eat me. I can see the farm that I used to live at just across the river, it's quite nice out here when there's nothing trying to kill you. I woke up today and heard someone using my well and the clanging of the rock. Is someone stealing all my things? I walk outside to see my friends from the other farm across the river helping out here, I feel relieved as now I can focus on other things while they do the hard work. TLDR: If you're into a Village Building, Squad Tactis game with some RPG mechanics that's what this game is offering right now, not too much in the way of RPG right now but the games not finished yet. It's mainly just a build your own village right now, but it does a very good job at that. I definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 2
Early Access Review
								Went on a solo run with my main character to explore.Found a sweet old armoury with so much loot...heavy♥♥♥♥♥loot.Got greedy and decided to take as much as possible.Crap...encumbrance at 80 percent. Slow♥♥♥♥♥running.This is when the death march back to civilization began.Spiders, spiders everywhere. Took out the first few groups and bandaged up but began to get more and more beat up.Group of 8 spiders got me. Knocked me out and crippled my leg.Didn't die! Woke up but now even walk slower with crippled leg.Crippled leg and crazy amount of loot in inventory. I will not give up any loot. Too greedy. Keep walking at snails pace.Spiders again. Knocked out. Wake up. Spiders again. Knocked out. Wake up. This is my death march.Happens a dozen times and then i realize that i left all my food at the armoury to make room for more loot.So now I'm starting starve to top it off. Still a long way from civilization. Damn spiders. No fabric to make bed to sleep and heal. Starvation issue becoming more dire. So much amazing loot in backpack.No slavers around. No cannibals around. I might be ok. I am a walking living treasure chest for whoever decides to beat me up and steal all my glorious loot.Watch distance to town get smaller, as well as my stomach. Can i make it before i starve or run into slavers?Roll into town about 20 points away from death. Skinny as hell. Eat glorious meatwraps. Sell loot i dont want. Profit from deathmarch? Almost 175 grand. Greed paid off. Would death march all over again. One of my many adventures. Love this game. Support it. Buy it. Damn spiders.

content:
Posted: April 20
Early Access Review
								So, I've only played Kenshi for a few hours so far and I will be honest it's been a strangely lovely experience. I have felt more immersed in this unusual game with graphics that remind me of the original dungeon siege games than Pillars of Eternity or Dragon Age, games designed just for that. I can't tell anyone what the progression will be like but I can tell the little story I've already created in my head from just a few hours has been, which made me laugh out loud and have to retell it to my girlfriend.I begun my adventure in a waypoint, barely able to comprehend the floor system and feeling completely useless and daunted. No one wanted to speak to me, there are very few npc's around who have dialogue except barman, potential companions and traders. I was unsure what to do; there are no quests, only a few tutorials to help guide you. I figured I should buy a water jug and saw another town on the horizon. Why not travel there, explore the lands and see what is offered. Kenshi is huge, you have to use the speed up options to cross these great canyons and deserts. I spent my first day travelling to the closest town I could see, which was actually an abandoned town with no one in it. However there was a copper ore vein, so I mined it. I had a dream of becoming a wandering swordsman, but this felt distant and mining was the first interactable thing I could do, so why not? Maybe I could sell the ore and buy a sword instead of this wooden club? Turns out swords are insanely expensive so maybe not.I tried to run back to the town where I started, but realised I was lost (I have later discovered that if you zoom into the map, more places are visable, duh) and found some bandits instead, waiting on the road. There was at least 20 of them, I was no match I knew it so I gave them 300 gold. Then, I had the option to talk to some of the bandits. Maybe they were friendly bandits now? I spoke to him, he demanded that I gave him 300 gold. Apparently not friendly then, I am a naive surviver of the apocalypse. I declined, as my money was already running short so he attacked me. So I ran. Apparently, that is something I am good at. I quickly out ran them, found another copper vein and mined a little more. I was getting better at mining at least.I explored, ran away from more bandits and mined a little more, selling some ore for food and a sleeping bag. Some hungry bandits chased me but luckily a group of slavers were there to help me out, defeat all the bandits with my assistance. Suddenly I had a t shirt, some terrible bandit gear to sell and things were looking good. The slavers looked preocuppied and I noticed they were picking up the unconscious bandits. I guess they were named slavers for a reason, but they wern't interested in me so I decided to carry on. I bandaged myself up but had a horrible limp but felt victorious and hopeful, I was progressing and had my first set of 'better' items.Eventually, I found the shek capital. In the bar their was a shek girl with broken horns. She asked me what I thought about fighting to the death, and I instantly decided to lie and said that is exactly what I would do and that I would never run when outnumbered. She wanted to join me (for free), and even though I still dreamt of becoming a lone swordsman, at least to begin with I could get the help of this shek women. We trained for a while with some training dummies, I had melee attack skill to 10. I felt ready to take on anyone. We left town and saw a tech trader walking down the road. It's time to test out our new skills, let's attack! At exactly the same time, 10 hungry bandits joined in the fight. The lone trader was armed with a katana and ruined us and all the bandits, leaving us all unconscious. I am not ready to be a lone swordsman yet it seems, but I suddenly wanted to be like him. When we woke, we took everything from the bandits (a cleaver, finally a better weapon), heal up and as it turned out, mine some more.On our way back to the shek capital yet MORE bandits attacked us. Spurred on by the lie I had told my companion, we decided to stand our group, outnumbered 6 to 1. Naturally, we were oblitterated. The same hero slavers who had saved me earlier in the game walked past, spyed us and heroicly destroyed these pesky bandits. Amazing, I love slavers. However, this time, we were the ones picked up. When we recovered enough to walk, we tried to limp away. Nope. The slavers came to us, knocked us both into COMAS and started walking towards the hub. COMAS. They dropped me on the ground, bored of carrying me I guess, just outside the shek city where I lay in a COMA for another 12 hours recovering from a stomach injury. My companion was halfway to the hub now. When I woke up, I picked my shackles, and stumbled into town to heal. In my hurry, I forgot to actually take off the shackles and the guards preceeded to knock me out into ANOTHER coma and put me in a jailcell. My companion was dumped on the road just south of the hub by these lazy, devious slavers who like to steal people and dump them randomly in the desert in comas. When she woke up she ran/limped back to come save me.She was sensible enough to take off her shackles and went to town to resupply when I bravely tried to escape the cell. Which took ages. She then proceeded to sneak to the guardhouse in the dead of night and wait for me to escape. It was 5.50am, almost dawn when I succeded. But how were we to escape? I was wanted by the entire city. But she wasn't. So she picked me up, slung me over her shoulder and ran out of town as an unsuspecting shek citizen. We ran to the nearest hill, shared a sleeping bag taking it in turns to rest up while the other mined (I was getting pretty good at mining). We had escaped, now we just had to avoid large settlements and mine and sell ore. I had a new dream now. No longer did I want to be a lone swordsman. I wanted my own group of companions. I was tired of being attacked by bandits and slavers, left in comas on the floor and then beaten up by alien guards and thrown into jail with my second coma of the day. I decided I would become a bandit myself. Suddenly, I had a plan...Never has a game made me subconsciously narrated such an indepth story in such a short time, especially without barely any dialogue. And thats why, even though I don't know if the game will be good or bad in the long run, it doesnt matter because of those first 4 hours.

STOP HITTING ME BEAK THING!!!80 hours in: BUGMASTER WHERE ARE YOU100 hours in: My name is Max. My world is fire and blood....Summary: Starts of really wonky and questionable, then you fall instantly in love with the very unusual universe. Mad Max with ninjas, except you suck at everything and aren't Mad Max. You'll get captured, get eaten alive, burn yourself in acid, starve to death, run for your life, but most of all, you will have adventures that I have not seen possible in any other game. Comes with a free mod toolkit for you to design your own game starts or characters if you feel so savvy.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is a very ambitious, low budget game. Unfortunately this usally results in a very undirected, dull experience and Kenshi is no exception to this rule. My experience progressing through this game was very unsatisfying. For a good portion of the game none of your characters will ever be strong enough to kill any of the animals or humans you encounter in the world. The most feasible way to progress I found, was to game the system by stealing valuable items from settlements that should have been defended were it not for bugs, or by leading enemy packs into guards then selling their equipment back to the people who killed them. If there were any legitimate ways to make a living in this game I was not able to find them. The world of Kenshi may be huge but there is so little to do other than run from stronger enemies while scrounging for abandoned loot to sell.What's rather impressive is the party system which allows you to split your tribe into smaller groups who are then able to travel all around the world in real time. However, loading between areas isn't instant, so while you'll want to constantly switch between groups to ensure that none are in danger, generally this will mean most of your time will be spent waiting for terrain to load.I don't believe the party system scales well either. For every group it takes nearly all your concentration to spot and avoid enemies. If you are split between two groups this becomes impossible so that the best strategy by far is to strip down all your survivors in order to outrun any enemy rather risk fighting some of them. This game would greatly benefit from some kind of spotting skill to empower the ai to avoid groups that are too strong, or at the very least it should include some kind of warning system.In short if this game had a team twice as large they might have been able to fill this world with interesting content but as it stands there's not much to do other than running around, hiding from enemies.

Early Access Review
								This game has much promise and I can see people from many genres liking at least one aspect of it. It has the cruelty of a souls games yet the potential for total all out war that you would find in a game such as age of empires, or rise of nations. You can develop your faction and co exist with others like you would in civilization or go it alone like a true rpg. Like any other sandbox game you can do what ever you like! It's not even complete and I love it already!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								-IMPORTANT - > The first thing you should know about this game, is that the Devs care. I first realized this when the updates came not with speed, but with good, quality content. The Devs do not rush updates to make people happy, they are not filled with fluff and pointless things, but instead are filled with bug fixes and content that truly help advance the game state. In fact in a recent news post about an upcoming update the devs said "•Entirely new world map.  More detailed and polished, new factions, new content, things to explore.  Its' like Kenshi 2.  Crazy.  I should have called it Kenshi 2 and charged for it again, but I didn't.  Damn." That comment right there just shows you that these devs understand what other Early Access developers do, and that they are not like those other early access developers.Now for how I feel about the actual game. This game takes time to get a lot of enjoyment out of it, but you do get just that. In most starting scenarios you choose from, you are dirt poor, and you are nothing close to a hero. Kenshi is not easy, you'll most likely die quite a few times at the start. As time progressive you gain more members to your squad and your existing members become more experienced. There is a really great feeling that comes when your squad finally becomes strong enough to destroy a group of bandits without any outside help. Eventually you will be able to build an outpost, which if you do not build incorrectly can be quite difficult (and by incorrectly I mean not building a stone mine and building materials producer first thing). Eventually you will be able to build research stations which allow you to learn how to farm and create your own items such as armour and weapons. Even balistas and walls can be build eventually. If you put in the time this game can be vary rewarding, and best of all, a huge update is coming out quite soon, which will greatly improve the game. I 100% recommend giving this game a try, you will not be sorry.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								When I first found Kenshi it was but a poorly formed early stage physics game set in the deserted land of God know where, I fought to create my kingdom and would eventually stick around long enough to see my squad grow large, slavers invade the land and cannibals rampage recklessly.Then things got stale, as progress was slow at best, I left for probably a little over a year, checking back here and there to see what's up.Thing's have really changed around here, the landscape is majestic and diverse(v90.X), the engine can still be slow at times but I am also running it on as high quality as the settings allow, which aren't too bad.My story starts in Western hive, I awake with my new found sword, a hefty bounty on my head of 10000 cats and basically nothing to my name, as I spend the early time exploring I quickly come to realize that while I can buy raw meat to cook I can't actually cook it around the hive or they will think I am stealing from them, and let me tell you having the entire hives personal army after you can be a scary sight.Once out of the immersive jungle atmosphere I found a familar sight of mountains followed by long flat sands. I made my way East.  Stumbling upon a large city, which I avoided once I realized the holy knights of whomever didn't like me so much, I turned North, towards a small mining community, there I learned the basics of sneak and thieving before eventually being chased out by the guards.  They didn't have much to offer anyway.Through the crashes as I tried to head into a misty valley I quickly turned back East and made my way to some small farming houses, here I learned the basics of Assassination, spending my time quickly smacking some basic farmers across the head and waiting for them to regain conciousness so I could do it again, it was a good chunk of fun watching my failures turn to *Thunk*s, but the holy paladins would eventually find my shenanigans and chase me out.From here I would venture further North, then East into the mountains, I had stolen just enough food from the farmers to get myself over the mountains.  It wouldn't be long before I would eventually find another mining community, here I truly refined my skills and smacking people over the head, and when I was all done and good I jailed the guards and freed the prisoners, who would for some ungodly reason choose to stand inside their unlocked cells permanently.  Whatever.After my skills in sneaking, thieving, and Assassination where at an all time high (and after battling through some crashes) I found myself back on the road and heading south, I needed food pretty bad, even if I had enough to tide me over for the next day or two.  Heading South in the mountains I ran into a strange man from the Adventurers guild, Paste was his name.  He never saw me, he was unconsious in seconds and before long I was trading my shirt and pants for his ninja garb, leather shirt and hat.  All of course of high grade quality.  I needed not for his weapons and left him to fight his way out wearing the trash I had just discarded.From his dreamland body I made my way up the nearby mountain where I ran into some ninjas, none of which seemed to rule the roost and all seemed quite pleased to simply sleep and smack the training dummies all day.  I joined in on this fun and boosted my otherwise pitiful swordplay to a reputable level.  Before long I tired of their boring game, and made my way back on the road.It was from here that I faced my true challenge, running farther south through the mountains I noticed a tower on the hill, hoping for more fun like the ninjas (but better) I made my way towards it.  As I reached the main gate I realized I had come across the main hideout for the Dust Bandits.  Oh how those buggers had long been a thorn in my side in patches previous.  It was time to see what they were hiding.Inside all but an unobservant sentinel were asleep on their bed mats, even the king of the bandits himself.  From this dangerous ground floor I made my way up and up to the prisoners floor, where I met poor old stupid Cat.  What an idiot, getting himself captured under the false pretense of being a noble.  Annoying to talk to as well.  I knew the king had to  be carying something worthwhile as his bounty nearly tripelled my own, 30k cats.So after talking to the buffoon cat, I waited and ambused one dust boss after another, until all 9 cages and 2 chain spikes had a prisoner attached, and there is poor old cat, unlocked chains and he's lost his mind, unable to leave from the shackles he has spent the past few seasons attached to.Not my problem though, I knock out the king and loot myself a beautiful new shirt, better than the last.  I proceed upstairs so I can unlock a nearby chest, looting all the bandits food supplies + a new small backpack to carry it in.Made off like a bandit in black, just before crashing again.Anyway,TL;DR immersive game, multiple play styles, okay graphics, choppy at times, loading can be annoying, map isn't full sized yet but speaks volumes for what it will be.  Talking to NPC's is sub par, sneaking system very easy to manipulate and break, same with assassination skill.  Thieveing a bit harder to bump up but seemingly good system.Great game if you can work around the current crashes and stability issues, very excited for the vision this game is headed for 7/10 currently, potential for 10/10 in the future.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								As it stands, this game too unpolished and has a long way to go until it is running as you would expect. If the developer(s) can deliver what this game sets out to be however, i will probably be spending as much free time as possible playing it as the potential is amazing. Just too many limitations as it stands, for example i spawn in some area and the map shows a town nearby, i go to visit this town and am greeted with a 'beta limitation prevents you from going any further' or something along the way. Head back the way i went to see if can discover another town somewhere and get killed by a boar or something, lol. There seem to be regular updates but at the moment when something gets fixed and several new issues arise. Saying that, if you enjoy Mount & Blade then you should enjoy this as it is a similar sort of game just in a different setting. With all that said this game is a tremendous amount of fun and i for one am willing the developers to get it completed as even with the content thats currently available, once its all working and running as it should then this game would be worth double the asking price.

content:
Posted: April 23
Early Access Review
								The freedom in this game is amazing, you can do everything you want.The combat system is one of the nicest of ever seen, but can be very frustrating at some point.Training of your characters is a long process of grinding teeth and smashing keyboard, as you will be losing nearly every fight you get into, and especially at the start it will force you to alot of screenstaring before you can play again, waiting for your guys to heal up.Every little mistake is punished brutally hard, some early mistakes will haunt you later on in the game, rushing things will get you in trouble, the game is very unforgiving, and at times you even wonder if the game is even any fun at all, as you will get annoyingly frustrated at nearly every aspect of the game.From graphics, to Ai pathfinding, to combat to building, everything has something that will annoy the hell out of you, top this off that the game will put your PC to its limits, since the game is badly optimized.I cannot recommend it in its current state, unless you are able to cope with frustrations well, and have the patience of a dead cat.Still the game is somehow dispite it all, kinda fun and addictive and unique.But it needs stil alot more time to evolve its gameplay, as half of the features are incomplete or even missing, and that what is in, all has issues/bugs to a certain point.The interface is a utter mess, and doesnt handle big number of NPC's, but the game is all about having alot of NPC's working for you, so here it shoots itself in its feet. The Ai is still WIP and will make you cuss and swear hard at times, even make you wonder if they ever will get this right, if that is in a game on this scale even possible.Still yet what they have done in this regard is remarkable, but it does make you wonder if they arent pushing it to far, and that its even possible Ai wise to every get this working perfectly.This is one of those games, that is pushing the bounderies of gaming, giving a unique game that cannot fully be compared to other like-wise games, mostly due its scale and size with absolute freedom.And its logical this comes with a price, and the price is a very... extreme long development time, so i play the game now and then, to a point where you really notice its pretty much WIP and trying to play it further just makes you hate the game too much.And still.... if you can deal with this all.. its one of the most original hardcore brutally hard games out there, with topics most other games dont even dare to touch, slavery, extemetism, narcotics, crime and even cannibalism and opression, its all there.And some factions will put your moral compass to the test, and uther loathing them for what they stand for.I never had such feelings in any other game for virtual factions, but in this game, i really have a deep hatred for some of the factions views and laws...This is a game that you want to see completed, but you prolly have to wait a very long time before its done.Very fitting for this game, as the gameplay is nearly as slow as its development.I recommend this game only to those who can deal with the game, its certainly not a mainstream game.IF you cannot deal with bugs, unpolished gameplay, long development time, and frustratingly hard gameplay, with every odd stacked against you, you will not like the game at all..

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is absolutely great for generating your own personal stories. Better so than most games of its ilk. It starts off at a grindingly slow pace, but once it gets going you'll have developed a deeply personal attachment to your first four or five guys in your party. Let me tell you one that I am very glad I experienced.Roud, A weak, hot headed man half starved and an injured arm has just barely escaped with his life from his sacked hamlet. The lone surviver and least respected of his people, is now thrusted into an unforgiving world with nothing but a pair of torn pants and a lead pipe. On his first week he attacks a small group of starving bandits, quickly learning just how easily outmatched he is by even the most ill equipped of raiders. He only survives thanks to wandering band of merchants who tended to his wounds while he was passed out. Thankful for his saviors, he decides to follow them. The merchants tolerate him, despite his almost complete uselessness. Roud acted as one of their bodyguards, slowly building up his strength and being able to suffer a few hits from a rusty sabre. Always reassured in the knowledge that should be begin to fail, the other bodyguards would be willing to lend a hand. He had his share of the loot since the merchants didn't take any interest on what the bandits where carrying, only focusing on running goods from town to town. This didn't last long for Roud however, for after two weeks they encounterd a large, organized group of bandits.He fought hard as did his allies, even managing to down bandit or two on his own, but merchants steadily began dropping one by one, followed by the guards. The main culprit? The bandit leader, adorned in heavy armor and sword far larger and more thick than any man should be able to wield effectively. eventually Roud met the end of the hulking nightmare of a man and was struck down.Miraculously, he woke up to a pile of eviscerated corpses and nothing but a minor cuts on himself. He had merely passed out from bloodloss, a massive relief to him. Even more miraculously he found the corpses five bandits including their leader, the very one who had slaughtered guards and merchants alike with ease. A band of Samurai can be seen from the distance, no doubt the perpetrators of such an act. Roud ignored the small fry and immediately pilfered the massive man's body, adorning his armor and plucking his sword from his cold hands, only stopping to grab a helmet from the one of the other dead bandits. His face now hidden behind a metal mask, his torso protected by iron platemail, and massive sword so heavy he must drag it along the sand, he heads west towards the nearest town, the one he had left only a few days ago following the merchants. After such a defeat, only one thing rested on his mind: "I must become the strongest fighter in the sands". He exhausted, he's injured, he's carrying valuable loot, and more importantly he's alone. When he arrives in town, the first thing he does is rent a bed and collapse.When he awakes, his mouth is dry. He heads to the local pub and trades all but his most valuable loot to the barkeep in exchange for a decent sum of cash and a stiff drink. Out corner of his eye, an absolutely gigantic dark skinned man stands in the corner of the bar with his arms folded. In dire need of an extra sword, he saunters over to the giant and drops a sack of coins in front of the man. "Five hundred catts straight up if you join me" The dark skinned man only nods and steps forward, only uttering what can be presumed to be his name "De-Zerka" The two left town that evening to wander the desert. They had very few victories, but each fight left them stronger, more experienced, and more dangerous. The two became close friends, and eventually made it to the point they could cleave through half a gang of bandits before going unconscious. This was a blessing, as they proved too risky to risk staying in the same viscinity, unconscious or not; not to mention having to tend to the wounded, if not outright abandoning them.Eventually, the two realized the necesity for a third sword, more importantly one who can sow and bandage wounds. The next town they greeted a friendly, short and nimble woman, "Tuner". When asked if she knew her way with a medkit, she nodded and hired her on the spot. She proved skillful with a katana, and very effective at not getting hit.The three travelled for a long while, long enough to be feared by many wandering parties across the desert. Even the Holy Nation, very organized, and heavily armored knights with fanatical beliefs, felt threatened by them, though their patrols only served as fodder for the party's quest for becoming the best fighters in the land. Along the way even allowing a Fourth member, "Hanbu", an man of average size, stout legs, and a firm back. He served mainly as the pack mule, carrying a large backpack for most of their loot to be stored. Even he became a formidable foe to fight against.By now, Roud had become a very skilled in his own right. His own hot headedness made him very aggressive, often charging straight into the enemy and going berserk. Not even a broken arm, cracked skull, and a knife in his gullet could stop his rampage. De-Zerka as well, wielding the looted armor from Holy Nation and weapon more reminiscent of a long, metal paddle than a sword, becoming renown for destroying a man's skull in one swing. Tuner kept mostly to the sidelines, choosing to pick off the bandits from the flanks rather than risk charging headfirst into danger. She was easily the fragile of the group, but most effective at dealing with the small fry.But this party would soon meet it's untimely end, their quest cut short.On their usual run between towns they  see a strange sight ahead. A gigantic mob swarming around the settlement. Upon further observation they realized it was cannibals. They would always travel in large groups, but never have they seen one as large as this. Their numbers were so many that their howls and cheers could be heard from miles away. At least 5 or 6 hundred of them. Not willing to travel to another town and feeling heroic, the party decides to attack the mob head on.The Cannibals came pouring from the gates, some of them carrying the unconscious residents with them and easily surrounded the party. Roud, whipped into a fury, charges deep into the mob, cutting down cannibal left and right while De-zerka, Tuner, and Hanbu instead of following him, stayed behind, choosing to cover their backs and fight defensively. Roud fought valiantly, but each hit the cannibals were able to connect with him wore him down. Slowly, but surely. All around him lie corpses, yet the chanting, screaming mass of ugly, tatooed abominations surrounding him were unfased. He had made a significant dent in their numbers, but there were still far too many to be considered done.A cry rings out, Hanbu had been struck dead. Tuner panics and runs through the thinnest part of the crowd, fleeing for her life as ten or fifteen cannibals give chase. Roud, distracted and dishearted, takes a blow to the head. He staggers, his vision blury, and he swings his massive sword into the crowd. Another blow, this to his arm: it dangles by his side, effectively usless in the situation. He continues to swing his sword, furious at his sloppyness, the death of one of his comrades, and the betrayal of another. No matter how many cannibals he slaughters it seems like no use as they wittle him down to the point where he can barely stand. He sees passed the crowd one of the tribal monstrosities carrying De-Zerka over his shoulder.... This was it... this is his last battle and it only took him until now to figure it out. He can barely muster enough strength to swing his sword one last time before a pipe to his head fells himBy the way the last bit was in no way an exaggeration, the game bugged and accidentally spawned a gazillion of cannibals. Good game

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is early access, like super early access. It's got bugs, and issues, and crashes from time to time. But its got potential, and already has many working features. But I love the game to bits already. Options are numerous is very custimizable, varied starting choices, even got mods!Some people fear that this game will never be finished; that it's just a cash grab, well they're wrong. The developer has monthly updates with what they're working on, what new features, races, etc are being planned.It's a giant endeavor, and the one single developer and a couple of hires are working as hard as possible to make updates live, but its slow work yes.If you're looking for a complete game, get the ♥♥♥♥ out now. But if you're looking for that something that fun that could consume hours upon hours of your time, this is it.You're looking for that 100% open world game, this is it.You're looking for something to hope for, to once more confirm the belief that a game in early access can become great? This is it right here.They even got a demo if you're unsure about buying the game yet!It'll be a slow process, but I am 100% behind this game and the developer(s)!More information at http://lofigames.com/

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
Early Access Review
Imagine if Mad Max was made by Akira Kurosawa.A desert world, bleak, hostile, vast.  Sparsely populated by junk towns and populated by newborn cultures based on old black & white samurai films, with a touch of the spaghetti westerns born thereof thrown in for good measure.  Men and women in coolie hats with katanas fighting against groups of bandits and crazed cannibals, trying to build secure outposts of safety in a violent and chaotic world.This was the game that advertised back when I bought into it.  This was the game that was promised.  Does this sound like a great idea for a game?  Does this sound like a game that you would want to play?  Well tough crap, suckers, because all that is going bye-bye!Welcome to a fantasy world filled with lush jungles, mysterious forrests, dangerous wolf packs, and strange races - bone men, bug men, and robots.  Oh joy, robots!  And giant monster things!  That's just what every samurai adventure needs, right?  That vast wasteland that took hours to cross is now a map ten times larger!  Why?  Because we can.  Not that you'll ever get any use out of that, but so what?  This game is no longer about wandering ronin traversing the desert in search of adventure.  It is now the living avatar of feature creep, fueled by what seems like some kind of unending mescaline binge and slowly morphing into new game entirely... a game that's only common denominator with the original is that there are swords.And all this has been while continuing to fail at fixing bugs that are literally as old as the game itself.  Constant crashes, dysfunctional pathfinding, and broken tools thrown around like a gas explosion in a mechanic's garage.  Rather than fix the game they already had they instead decided to turn it into a RTS version of Morrowind, only weirder, if you can imagine such a thing.Now maybe that is a game that you'd be interested in and I won't begrudge someone for liking that, but personally I don't care for the bait and switch.  I certainly do not appreciate the constant adding of more crap that I don't recall anyone asking for while everything that came before it is still horribly broken.I saw an idea, a great idea, for a game that I would like to play.  I paid for that game.  Today I see a completely different game being made, one that I simply have no interest in, while the one I bought was never finished - and never will be.So if you're looking for a high-fantasy, RTS version of your favorite magical wonderland, go right ahead and get Kenshi.  If you're looking for the post-apocalypse desert wandering ronin adventure originally advertised on the box then you're out of luck - keep looking, maybe someday, someone will make that game for real.Final note: Posting this as a review since I was being banned from forum for saying the same things.  In the comments below you can read where the moderator tries to deny this.

								The game is exactly what you would expect from it, the pictures give out alot about the game. though the game has been in development for over 8 years now, its recent sucess as a green-lit steam game has enabled the team to grow ( 6 now), the game is pushing beta soon as many great features are being implimented. content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is a RPG-RTS featuring a slow progression and massive learning curve. It's core features, being RTS battles and Dwarf Fortress-like base building, are made more complex with every patch. Though, it does lack somethings, for instance: The beginning starts you out fairly weak, even the beginnings geared towards making you more combat ready only leave you with a powerful weapon against an army of more experienced bandits.The difficulty fluctuated heavily a few hours in though. Even after amassing an army, you still aren't strong enough to take on a single bandit party. However, when you reach a point, and you've leeched a few kills off of guards with your squad of cowards, you're able to leave the game running with no fear of attack -- or agency. I'd automated an entire camp. Random events and the like, a feature of base-building games that it emulates, would and have been a boon. This game could easily be the greatest game I ever play -- the potential is there. I need that 3D dwarf fortress.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Game:Kenshi is a game that can't be catagorized. It's a beautiful, sword-punk blend of RPG, RTS, and to some extent a city builder/Sims-style survival game where you cater to basic needs. The demo does the game little justice, and many people who rate it poorly probably never experienced the transition of this game into what it is now. The developers are committed to creating a living world, and tailors an RPG-style game where you are no hero. Even if you choose a start that makes you top dog when it comes to the scum of Kenshi, you bite the bullet. Pros: -Multiple ways/"genres" to play.-Multiple settings for adjusting the difficulty, for better or worse.-Beautiful world, at least for an independently developed game. -Creature/racial artwork and variety is unique, and funnily deceiving (cute goats that can massacre a small squad).-Dedicated development team, which has proven itself over the long-term.-Lots of replayability, and even punishing starts can have a silver lining.-Combat can be sometimes frustrating, but always beautiful to watch, with drastic outcomes based on even the smallest decisions.-Character customization can be oddly entertaining, and...-Mechanics can be easily caught onto, and easier to work around with a little time and effort.Cons:-Bugs. Lots and lots of bugs. It was much worse at the initial release of the Beta, but within a week or so the most game breaking were patched. -The Dev team actively makes use of bug reports, even catering to some very specific issues players faced in the past.-World can be laggy, even on a good computer. This is, however, on high graphics and almost exclusive to high density bandit zones or rendering of the map.-Updates may feel slow, but minor ones with huge impacts are frequent.-Game can crash due to random errors introduced with an update (commencing specific research, as an example when the game entered beta), but these are once again usually patched within a day or few.-Can be painfully punishing, and some mechanics are unrefined, but bear in mind many mechanics are fresh to the beta and much of it is an EXPERIMENTAL build.Kenshi isn't everyone's cup of... well, dust and rust. Despite this, its flexibility, originality, and progression through the years has proven it a capable contender and worth the attention.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Probably the most effective genre-busting game in its' time. It's real, -real- post-apocalyptic game that doesn't teach you anything easily and lets you figure the game out as you go, and if you're an idiot, you'll be killed. Be a smart survivor - Realize that people are absolutely insane who live in the wastelands and will likely rob you, or at the very worst, outright eat you limb by limb. - And those in the cities treat you as far as your money can throw you. . Passed that, they will let you die from starvation, don't care if you bleed out in the streets and die, may rob you - or they might  join you in your cause. . as long as you have the money to sway them. You can be anything from a Adept Scavenger quick on their toes and trade goods for great profit between towns, to a bandit crew who massacres a farmers village for their base and all of the goods within  - whom you can trade to a fence inside a town while in a disguise as to not alert Bounty Hunters or the guards of the nation whom you've killed their subjects, to a group of settlers trying to eek out an existence amidst the wasteland and start from a lowly village to a legendary town with an abundance of food and technology new to the post-apocalyptic world. You may learn of hidden locations, if you're lucky, and encounter a plethora of characters. . Though not all are friendly.You may be lucky and find a wandering traveler in which you can sell your goods, as well as purchase blue prints to upgrade your skill set or your very own Factional town - Of course you could just murder them and take all their goods, though you may incur a bounty that will cause you to be hunted by lawgiving police. - You could either turn yourself in and face a smaller stint in jail and/or be forced to slave away in the mines, OR you could become an infamous raider whose tales of dread are recognizable to everyone in the province. Of course,  you could always be successful noble and create your own Faction city in which all nations depend on for their trade and have the most legendary army that no one would dare question your authority. -- Or, if you were to be really ambitious, you could become an abolisher of slavery and take over the province as the rightful sire of the lands - if you're ready for hardship, effort, death, surprises, and ultimate victory.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								(This review was created on March 3rd, 2014. It may become obsolete sooner or later.)This game has potential. It really does. It's a sandbox in a steampunk neo-feudal Japan-esque setting. The dev has not clarified what's going on and probably won't tell us for a very long time. I bought this before it was released on Steam, and I have to say: It has grown. It has trading, city building, realistic warfare, a complex medic system, and a whole lot of other things. There is one major issue that has been plaguing the alpha: a good portion of the game progression right now is attracting bandits and luring them to town guards. Once you have accumalated enough "Cats" you can try your hand at founding a faction, building an army, then start a town. Recent updates have added more difficulty to maintaining your humble abode. Raiders will come knocking and try to extort money off of you and cannibals will invade and attempt to take you and your men to their kitchen. You can research new technology with a certain workbench, but I won't bother saying much since I have yet to experiment with it.So. Do I recommend this game? Sure, but not in it's current alpha state. If you want to invest in a gaem that has a bright future, go ahead and buy it. Just remember that it's alpha.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay where to start, While I am giving this a positive review let us take that at face value. I feel as if the game is good and is going to be great when finished but if judge the game by what it should be then we often give false review's. I see the game as fun to play as new content is added each time I find myself playing more and more. Now what I do see is a huge amount of bugs while they can be overlooked they are an annoyance that can all but bring me to not want to play for at least week, now I will cite an example of my own experiance, I was playing the game when two of my men were caught stealing the guards took them but didn't lock them up instead they just carried them and went to a guard position and just stood there holding my two men even after there time was up the two guards would not put them down I tried everything restarting the game, reseting squad positions, and even attaking the guards but it was to no avail, its little stuff like that what I cited that can make the game feel almost unplayable once glitch caused me to lose two of my best men in one run. I also question why would they put us in the most racist part of the map, almost making it impossible to play as the shek as new person to kenshi? Looking over it, I would rather have a more polished experiance with less content then a buggy large amound of content, overall though I can't talk bad about the gameplay though, its fun and addictive, building your own settlment or industry maybe even a small army, the choices make the game unique. I give the game in a conclusion a 7/10 a standard score which if the game is improved upon could easily be an 8 to 9 out of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you ever want a game to succeed, you must keep your players invested. If there's anything I can say about Kenshi is that it has definitely gotten me invested in bettering my character through hours of training. The first time my bad♥♥♥♥♥level 50 Attack and Defense character took down an entire cannibal camp, I felt like I had truly accomplished a feat (considering how much trouble I had with them in the beginning). Watching him cleave unhindered through their bare, tattoo-ridden bodies made me so happy, albeit a bit doubtful about my sanity at the time. I can safely say that Kenshi has finally fulfilled my desire for a squad-based game in which individual progression and background really means something to me.Now, I just want to address something that many of the backers of Kenshi have been pondering recently. Lately, Lo-Fi's been making some good progress, having implemented DX11 into the game (though it is very unstable), and added a new race and such, which is all great! But, simply said, it's still been very slow. However, I don't believe, like many people do, that this game is going too slow. In my opinion, and I feel as if people have forgotten this what with triple A games and the likes such as Star Citizen, indie developers should be slightly exempt from the time-frame criticism. I think this is especially true for a game like Kenshi, which hasn't even received that much funding. These guys need to make a living, and nagging them everyday isn't going to fix that. I guess you could say that I don't want people who are pursuing their dreams to be discouraged for going too slow.Keep it up, Lo-Fi. I still have high hopes for this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kenshi is a unique game that is finding its niche in a mix between an RTS, Sandbox-Builder and Survival game with possible future elements of an RPG. While it's still in Alpha it is a very well polished game that offers hours of play and even more replay-ability. It's definitely not a game for the easily frustrated because you'll find yourself starting as probably the weakest character in its yet-to-be-defined universe. Combat reflects a very realistic feel at the start: You're weak and everyone can and just about will kill you. It's a game of judging whether or not combat is really worth the possible outcome. Groups of 2-3 bandits will destroy you at the start so luring them back to larger groups is pretty much you're only option while you slowly build up the skills of your character. Having a large party will improve your odds but if they're still untrained it would be like sending a bunch of children to fight an adult. Yeah, they may overpower the adult but more than likely they'll all get beaten. There's already several ways to make money and the economy in the game is being tweaked. This just means you don't always have to fight bandits and other patrols to get the capital necessary to start your own outpost. Then when you have that the game definitely delivers several different ways of improving your little town and building your own army. I recommend trying this game out. There's a demo version of it available somewhere, in case you're the type worried about purchasing and not liking games still in development.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is a masterpiece. Despite the fact it's still a work in progress with some minor and some major tweaks. I first downloaded this game when it was F2P. It was a slow start, the game was very dry and I found myself getting bored very quickly. I didn't hesitate to delete it and this was I think, back in 2012. I decided to give it another go in early July 2016 and boy was I in awe. I honestly didn't know what to expect this go round but, I am definitely impressed with the direction the developers took with it. It's almost like you're absorbed in a fantasy world where self-preservation is key.  you kill, you starve, you build, you recruit and you defend what you work hard to accomplish. If the developers read this, I love sandbox games. I was kinda heavy in to "Omertà city of gangsters" I believe if Omertà had the mechanics that Kenshi has, it would not have been such a disappointment. Please develope a gangster game for all of us mobster fans.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Takes about 1-3 hours to get a grip on what's going on in the game and how to do anything. Once you grasp it, though, it's one of the most thoughtful and creative games you can experience. Lots of tiny details make it that much more realitic and thrilling to play. Plus, the aesthetic of the game is mad wicked. It's like steampunk without the autism. Many different ways you can play the game, many different paths to take, many different variations on how you do things. Overall best game I have played in a long while, a very good break from the monotony of today's gaming industry.It's relatively new, so there's a few glitches and bugs. It only really gets annoying if you have a big automated base and your farmers keep getting stuck under the stairs for no reason.However, this game is definitely worth it. It's worth a lot more than $20, I can't wait to see how they improve it. I'd recommend anyone to buy this (I already bought a copy for my friend).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do I recommend this game, Yes. But not for everyone.This game has the potential to be Frak'in amazing.  I've been following the game for a year or two, and their have been patches and addition that come relitively frequently.  Personally, I was hoping for the game to develope faster, but their are quite a few things that they are putting together, and the interactions between each Start location/faction/character skill/base construction/tech advance/and so on...  is a very complicated to balance and intagrate.The're quite a few bugs still in the system, like pathing issues, caravan guard "visits", building inaccesabilities and such, but they are slowing fixing bits and pieces. In recent patches, you have been allowed to assign tasks to your "villigers" and they would run arround and complete that task with no further intervention on you behalf; Which was an awesome upgrade from before.Remember before you continue to read this that the game is still alpha.But, to sum up some of the issues that are negitive. you have about 5 primary stats, and currently have access to 3 of them, of which one was only recently added (Toughness).  their are about 6 or 7 weapon skills, of which you currently have access to only 4 of them, and unarmed is not one of them. their are about 20 or so skills, like armor smithing, weapon smithing offence, defence, medic, labourer, engineer, science, and a couple of others. You have access to all of these skills but their are about half that you don't have access to. Again this game is still in Aplha!The awesome thing is that what is planned is things like, renting a building in a City to use a as a store front. Being able to replace severed limbs with robotic ones. Building cities, creating trade routes, starting you own faction (possably even your own empire) and so on.I'd like to recommend this game to everyone, but some people will not be able to enjoy it becuase its not completed, yet.I would advise to those people to add it to their wish list and follow the updates as they come out.To those of you who don't mind a game that is in the works, and can play though and help identify bugs, strap on a sword and come adventuring/build a city/trade with npc's/scavenge the unconsious bodies of the fallen/ or just plain become the scourge of the wastes, this game's for you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								Purchased this game back in April of 2013, played it for around 8-10 hours, then put it on the back burner. Came back a little over a week ago, and have since put 50 hours in. This game has improved so much its crazy, I love it too much.Start with the drawbacks-- Pretty buggy, but there is usually a work around that is a little inconveniant but fixes the issue for a while. - Pathfinding is hilariously bad- pretty hard if you dont know what your doing- no real intro to the game or what to doHere are the reasons i stick around - + Completely open ended, this is a hugeeeeee turn on for me (Could be a negative if you need set goals, as there are none)+ Love the building crafting system+You are free to have a squad of just you, or a squad of loads of people (more than 10 needs some mod help (but you can have 30 in vanilla, just split in 3 squads))+ Learned curve is satisfying, not too steep, but its there. + Loads to explore, and a ever present sense of danger+ Getting a charactor OP in stealth is pretty fun/funnyStuff Im not really into / Dont know much about - | I dont do combat much, i am mostly just a trader with a walled off town, i fight pests, not people| Cant say much about the experiance with other races, as i play soley human, because i like the protection of the holy nationTo be honest, the bugs in this game drive me up the wall, and make me clench my fists in rage sometimes. They can get frustrating, and the lack of fps is annoy af, but i keep coming back, every time i rage quit due to a bug, or a bad battle, i always come back, i have had dreams about this game for chistsakes. This is the game *I* have always wanted, it may skew my judgement, but i would recommend it to anyone in a heartbeat.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Dope-a-lisious.  Very unique, completely fresh new game!  Nothing really to compair it to cause it's so one of a kind, except maybe (it's like WarBand, the best game of all time, except without the advanced combat sim but introduces crafting and building instead).  But open world sandbox RPGs are the way of the future!!  Still rather rough around the edges, I hope the devs keep chugging.  Specifically, it needs SOUND updates.  There are no battle souns effects which really takes away from the experience.  And the sounds that are included seem like a cheap quick afterthought... Needs some work dudes.  Also needs some general polishing overall.  But on the right track! And totally t*ts in it's current state!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you ever want a game to succeed, you must keep your players invested. If there's anything I can say about Kenshi is that it has definitely gotten me invested in bettering my character through hours of training. The first time my bad♥♥♥♥♥level 50 Attack and Defense character took down an entire cannibal camp, I felt like I had truly accomplished a feat (considering how much trouble I had with them in the beginning). Watching him cleave unhindered through their bare, tattoo-ridden bodies made me so happy, albeit a bit doubtful about my sanity at the time. I can safely say that Kenshi has finally fulfilled my desire for a squad-based game in which individual progression and background really means something to me.Now, I just want to address something that many of the backers of Kenshi have been pondering recently. Lately, Lo-Fi's been making some good progress, having implemented DX11 into the game (though it is very unstable), and added a new race and such, which is all great! But, simply said, it's still been very slow. However, I don't believe, like many people do, that this game is going too slow. In my opinion, and I feel as if people have forgotten this what with triple A games and the likes such as Star Citizen, indie developers should be slightly exempt from the time-frame criticism. I think this is especially true for a game like Kenshi, which hasn't even received that much funding. These guys need to make a living, and nagging them everyday isn't going to fix that. I guess you could say that I don't want people who are pursuing their dreams to be discouraged for going too slow.Keep it up, Lo-Fi. I still have high hopes for this game!

								how to kenshistart as wanderer with nothingsteal all the food when noones lookingrun to the top of the map and look for armoriesfind lvl 3 edgewalker weaponsbring large groups of bandits or cannibals to towns and get the guards to kill themloot the bodies and improve your armor to at least leather- if youre patient chain or if youre stealthy ninja garbacquire a companion, repeat until you have a large enough mixed band to take down bandit groups unassistedexplore + prospect until you find  a base with fertility iron stone and waterhire laborers,  fill backpacks with building materials and iron platesreturn to the area, and begin your settlement with a full crew of experienced, combat ready, well equipped characters.personally i prefer building my games this way as opposed to the freedom seekers or trader but thats all up to you. they all work with a little micromanagement

content:
Posted: February 19
Early Access Review
								Kenshi, this game has never failed to disappoint.  I've been with it since the greenlight, before there was even audio in the game.  I think that is probably the main point.  This game has been in development for awhile now but Lofigames has not done what other developers have done and simply abandoned the game.  Yes the progress has been extremely slow (small updates) but there have been constant updates.  Each time I come back to the game, yes I do stop once I've explored all the features, there is always something new to explore.  But the point is, it has never stalled out, there are always updates.  Lofigames has always continued on with development.  I'm not going to sit here and tell you about the features of the game.  Figure it out for yourself, just know that it will definitely be worth your time.

								I played the game thinking it wouldn't be that great and I was 19 minutes into it thinking "I'm not sure about this game" but then I kept playing. 30 minutes went by "I might refund this" 2 hours go by "how the hell did I get in trouble I didn't do anything... oh its because I'm a hive character." 6 hours into the game "Oh my god I love this game!" its  a great game that can be a bit addictive and I NEVER say that about RTS games. the only problem is that its not complete yet BUT they are doing updates so that's great to hear. there is a map limitation that you can't go past from just 1/4th of the world map. can't wait when they get all the updates done and unlock the full map to go exploring and adventuring.

content:
Posted: January 18
Early Access Review
								The developers are really taking their time with this one.  Upon release it's gonna be a great game.  They are fixing bugs and taking time to really make it fun.  I've seen this game grow over the past two years and it's really turning out to be a good g ame.It has a fairly steep, but rewarding learning curve, so be prepared to be frustrated early on as bandits overpower you.  They are making ways for you to run away from slavers asap and escape from slavery if you are attacked and knocked unconscious, then kidnapped by slavers.  Often early on, its simply easier to run from bandits than to get slaughtered.Early on, try to spend money on building up your team.  Having many low skilled npcs on your side is a huge bonus against the highly skilled enemies you'll face.  If you can, train them up on the training dummies in the towns before heading out to the dangerous wastes.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Do you remember the good old days with D&D and using your imagination and how invested you were in your characters? How you died early in the beginning over and over again in anguish? How you kept coming back to this painful experience because you were hooked?... That's Kenshi minus the magic and in a total new world with new races, new Lore and mystery. And yes very very painful in the beginning. As you can see I have put over 300 hours in this game and only scratched the surface of this game.By the way it is in Beta not Alpha and it is much more stable. The world is huge and only 1/3 of the world is open at the moment. If you have the patience with bugs and can contribute to the development, this game is well worth it!  Don't expect hand holding or that you start off  as the chosen  one... But just like the good old days, you can slowly and painfully be pleasantly surprised how strong you can become.

content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								A Squad-Based Sandbox RPG, where you can become and do (almost) anything you want.So I became a rotting carcass after my first encounter with a group of Dust Bandits. 10/10!I purchased this game a long time ago in early-alpha state with nothing more than a desert map trying to survive in my own created settlement. I set up a small trading caravan and travelled across the desert to purchase and sell good for the highest profit. I really enjoyed it but stopped playing for some reason I can't recall.Recently rediscovered the game and came back to a brand new world. Some amazing new features have been added, like a completely new map, new species (love the Shek and Hiver Races!), new skills, new researchh tree. Really Enjoyed it once more!For people who don't know if they should buy it, just do it. It takes a bit of time and practice to get used to the game, but once you do you're hooked!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								An RPG game with quite a nice graphical detail and quality. Kenshi is quite fun and addictive even though it's still in Alpha stage. It has a few bugs here and there (mainly movement), but they are normally just a slight annoyance. If you know and love the web browser RPG games Caravaneer and Caravaneer 2, you will probably love Kenshi as well. It is similar in many ways, with the difference being that Kenshi doesn't have a story line and is in 3D.Build version when I wrote this review: v0.74.32.Some tips I'd like to share with everyone who is new to Kenshi:-- Ctrl + Shift + F11 will probably be your best friend in the game when it comes to getting characters unstuck. -- If you are having problems renting a bed to sleep for your character to recover quickly, and you have more than one character in your party, use any of them to pick up whoever that needs a rest and place them on the bed. This allows you to use the bed for free as well. Recovery while standing still is a very slow process unless your characters have a high toughness value.-- Even with the fast forward button, Kenshi can still be fairly slow. The start of Kenshi will probably be a slow one unless you get lucky. Don't worry about creating a settlement early on as it isn't really important. I took about 100 game days to start establishing my settlement after I got enough money and was satisfied with my crew members' skill level.-- The training dummies provided at towns can only train melee strength until level 4. Don't bother leaving your characters to train after that because you'll be wasting your time.-- Make use of the melee defence button for weak characters. You can train their melee defence easily this way while buying time for your attacking characters.-- Loot high value items from bandits only (weapons, headgear, shoes, and armour). Keep an eye out for sand ninjas because their armour is nice and light, and so is their weapons. Take note that their stats are quite high though.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12
Early Access Review
								Like many others, I bought this game a few years ago. Back then I could only think of one thing: rough. Really rough. The UI was simple with very basic sliders, the sand on the ground was smoothed over as if detailed in microsoft paint, and the game was completely unforgiving. I revisited this game in 2017 and I can safely say everything that was rough about the game back then has been improved and ironed out including the unforgiving nature of the game.   This is one of my favorite games i've ever played because it fits a neat niche I didn't know I was searching for.  You create a character or a few and set out into a wasteland. To give players guidance, it is reccomended you start mining and selling until you can safely equip your character(s). From then on is up to the player to do what they wish be it mining, fighting, basebuilding, slaving, stealing, etc. This is a strategy game with real time combat. You select your character and right click on a potential threat, and your character fights. This is melee only combat, so battles are fought with swords, greatswords, katanas, etc. Depending on the skill levels of your characters and how geared they are compared to the threat will determine the outcome of total defeat, or victory. Player controlled characters have skills that can be trained to better cooking, fighting, mining, and smithing. To train these stats, the characters must do the action to progress. Training toughness for example is done by getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥♥whooped. Being downed in a fight and getting back up and surviving increases your toughness exponentially. This means you can stay alive and fight longer. This was such a great mechanic for me; in other strategy games, losing a battle would always have me restart to see if i could change the outcome. With this game however, if i lost a fight, I would try to get the character back up and limp back into town to recover. This mechanic is a small example of how the developer utilizes mistakes and losses and benefits the player with not only lessons learned, but stat boosts as well. The developer of Kenshi has made a game in which stories are unfolding for the player each time they play. With the open nature of this game, I've had plenty of intriguing moments. One in particular was mid game. I had a three characters all who wielded heavy weapons squaring up against seven bandits. My main character Jack swings his enourmous sword and staggers 4. I manevuer the other two around to get a better position but they're caught off gaurd and take damage. My tank named Bard breaks his right arm and has to use his back up weapon. As he swings he gets struck down and knocked out. I send my doctor Soo to heal him while my main character jack fights the remaining bandits. One by one the bandits dropped until the leader strikes down Jack. Soo sees this and enraged, pummels the bandit leader. Jack gets up clutching his broken chest. We need to get back into town before more show up, so Jack picks up bard and throws him over his shoulder. Jack and Soo both crippled and beaten limp three in game hours to find a town to rest their wounds. After resting up, they venture into the wasteland once again. I love this game.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Brutal, lovely, lonely, and wicked. There are many games, and there is Kenshi, too. Not since Dwarf Fortress have I had such a primal connection to a digital dude. Kenshi is like a greedy nerd, it steals all the good ideas around it and  claims them as it's own. And it is wildly successful, there are few sandboxes as interesting as this one. You'll set out to make a mark for yourself, but be lucky to not get obliterated by a herd of goats on your journey.It's a game that, as I can see in my 'Guy and his Dog' initial playthrough, wants you to explore it. There are a number of different launch conditions and each is different enough to warrant at least a gander. $20 is not a lot of money anymore, but Kenshi is sure enough a lot of game.Hardcore stuff, I couldn't recomment his game any higher. This is dystopia.

content:
Posted: January 20
Early Access Review
								A Squad-Based Sandbox RPG, where you can become and do (almost) anything you want.So I became a rotting carcass after my first encounter with a group of Dust Bandits. 10/10!I purchased this game a long time ago in early-alpha state with nothing more than a desert map trying to survive in my own created settlement. I set up a small trading caravan and travelled across the desert to purchase and sell good for the highest profit. I really enjoyed it but stopped playing for some reason I can't recall.Recently rediscovered the game and came back to a brand new world. Some amazing new features have been added, like a completely new map, new species (love the Shek and Hiver Races!), new skills, new researchh tree. Really Enjoyed it once more!For people who don't know if they should buy it, just do it. It takes a bit of time and practice to get used to the game, but once you do you're hooked!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been following this games since months, finally I made that hard decision of taking a risk of buying an Early Access game (I just Hate Early access games).However, I found that this was really worth the investment. Kenshi is a genre in itself. You are thrown with a single player (or a group depending upon your choice of gameplay at startup), to live in a harsh world. Now it is upto you as to how you play and what your objectives are. You can buy backpacks  and bulls and be a trader, or you can create industries and be an industrialist. You may choose to become a fighter and hire and train other fighters, to create a fighting squad and boast your power upon the world, or you might want to be an ordinary man (or women) trying to survive and live in this world. On the downside, the game is an unfinished product and has performance issues (The devs have promised to improve performance significantly in coming days), and bugs. But it is still very playable and appears like a Beta version, though it is listed as alpha.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really like this game, I'm not entirely sure why I do.  It could be the brutal difficulty, or the fact you can play about five different ways, and it feels like radicaly different games in doing so.1) Base building and trading2) Mercenary and Bandit hunting3) An RPG with a small well monitored team4) Grand stratagy with dozens or more soilders (I once had 256 at one time, all outfitted differently).5) All of the above at the same time.The game is a massive time sink, and I often find myself starting it up and playing it whenever I'm not sure what I'm in the mood for, or if it has updated recently.  It is a game where time goes to die, and you will find yourself at a loss of what happened to the last 12 hours of your life.  Overall, I recommend it to anyone who likes micro-management games with lots of little details to go over and make sure are working.Some downsides are, the graphics aren't the best, and there are some clip issues, and the base building could be a lot more natural, but I think even with those falls it works as a game.  But like I said, no idea why I like it as much as I do, just if you aren't sure about it, and you like micro-management stuff, well, give it a try!  If you don't like managing inventories and resource management, and always needing just a little more cash, not for you.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has a lot of good things going for it.  One of my favorites is the ability to choose how you wish to play, be it one man rpg or a squad based builder, whatever you like.  That said, the level at which it runs is just awful.  I've checked time and time again to see what might be bottlenecking my system on this game, in particular, but have found nothing to suggest it is anything but poor optimization.  I get that it's in alpha, beta, whatever, but it's been out quite a while.  I imagined it wouldn't run like♥♥♥♥♥♥anymore, but alas.  If you can get through the stutters, or hell, if you don't have them at all, great!  There's fun to be had with Kenshi!  I know I enjoy the game, but the performance issues have turned me off to it.  I look forward to seeing it in its final iteration, but til then, I'll be leaving this one alone.
