number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Oh my god this game. An alpha that i've consume so much hours and it's still the case to transform into weeks. The first time i saw those image and thoses tags i was like... what the hell... I MUST TRY THIS!!! and oooh boy i don't regret my choice. Kenshi is a squad based rpg where you're basicly a rat in a giant world. Depends on witch start you choose, the journey beggane with you, mostly with a pants a rusty sword, and you strove the desert to make your legend. In this game, your an ant at the very begganing. imagine that you, normal guy/guurl of all day decide to take a sword and start off you're companie. As you fight and fight, you'll learn what a true fight is. you can literraly see your character getting better at fighting. faster, wiser, deadliyer. Recruits other squad members, engineers, medics, fighter, then train and equip them : cloth, plate, mail, depends on your play style. like all plating knights style? alright. you love it fast and ninja style? alright! take what suit your play style. The fight system is an awesomly done speacking of dynamics and there is a limbs system that we can think of the fallout 3 limb system. If the Hp of a limb go to 0, either he or she won't be able to use that limb and if its a vital limb (head chest stomach) then they'll be K.O and need some medical attention. If the HP bar of thoses vital limb go to a certain negative treshold, those wounds are deadly. That's how you know that one of you mate have died in combat. This realistic mechanics also request of you to take care of your mate and leave them time to heal up, before going out and start murdering again. Go out in this majestic and awesomely well done desert. i'm totally serious here : i've passed several minutes just watching the dune, mountains and the horizon. ALOT of work as been put into the enviroment, and you feel it as soon as you have that sand in your sandals. Also, the map is ENORMOUS. Sometimes i was even saying to myself : jeez... i have to walk all that? but the reasons i'Ve just said make that you want that walking experience in this wounderful desert. Make a gigantic and prosperous town or a secret Samurai HQ, trades, fight, you really are the master of your own destiny. no missions or objective, simply survive and make a good and badass living. it's a sandbox where you do what you want and of course what you can to survive. Start off as a battleground looter to a blademaster to a rich caravan traders, to a formidable bandit or cannibal hunter, Be a bounty hunter and capture bad guys for ransom, or be the inquisitionning justicar and bring their judgment. the choice is yours. your blade awaits and the sand is thisty for blood. Get that game and start your legend!!!P;S : sorry for the tones of grammar errors.Have a great day wandering the dunes!

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is a lot of fun, but be prepared to wipe a lot. The game will require you to sell better loot, and farm near towns for a long time. You can travel with a caravan, but beware that they will continue without you. So, if someone in your group goes down than heal them(let them recover on their own) and keep moving with the caravan or you'll be left behind. Don't think numbers alone will save you either. I've had a full group and been wiped by a couple of sand ninjas before.... Still an awesome game. Still in alpha, so it has its share fair of problems, but it's playable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								An interesting, innovative game created by one guy. In it's early Alpha stages it's completely playable, but with minor bugs and some major crashes. If you're a fan of Mount and Blade's open world, KOTOR's combat, and Elder Scrolls's skill system then you'll have a blast with this game. Along with the similarities to the title I previously listed, Kenshi also has a fully creatable town system where you can craft buildings, create your own town, sell your wares to NPC travelers and merchants, and get raided by bandits. It's a unique experience and a fun, slow-paced game where every squad member counts, and every swing of the enemies sword could mean death to your party.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
Early Access Review
Kenshi - A RPG mixed with some tactics and base-buildingDid you ever want to play a RPG where your character was not the chosen one until you achieved the skill to be him? Did you ever want to play a game where you can play with a single or multiple characters with pros and cons for each style? And most of all: Did you want a game with an open world where you can build your own outpost which can produce materials, weapons a.s.o.? If you don't mind some bugs and pathfinding problems (only sometimes) then even the alpha is good for you.You begin with a character for whom you first choose the background. There are a few backgrounds you can choose from and each changes the difficulty (i.e. you get a better weapon or none at all, have a squad or are a loner...). So you begin on a big map (which shall get bigger as the development continues) and don't have a real goal. Except to survive. Bandits may find you very fast and the first thing you REALLY want to do is run away. You need experience. The levelling system is like in Oblivion: You get better as you do it. So now you should get to the next city or a patrol. Bandits are Bandits and you don't have the experience to fight them. Like I said: You are NOT a hero. As you venture to the towns you may find better equipment and buy it from money you got for selling looted stuff from dead bandits or ninjas. Maybe you even find better thins on them, but that does not happen very often. To get the best equipment you need to produce them on your own. As soon as you have got money and found a safe place (not too far from a city would be best) you can begin to build a research bench and begin building an outpost. It takes a lot of time. Many hours (real time, not the ingame time) until you researched everything. You also need to buy some blueprints for better weapons and armors. Now that you have even better equipment you can do more in a fight and if you already have more experience, you can take on at least 1 or 2 enemies at once. Since I only played to this point, I cannot go further with the gameplay. Oh, did I mention you can lose limbs? And need to bandage your wounds? There are no health potions and it takes a lot of time to recover. Conclusion:Pro:- Huge map- Learning by doing- Build your own outpost/city- Research- Limbs can be severed- Different weapons with different playstyle- Research better weapons- Not as easy as most of the games nowadaysCons (at the moment):- Still alpha (includes bugs and similar problems)- No animals- Mines can be build anywhere- World seems very empty- Cities are small- Even if more guys around sometimes 1on1Neutral:- No AAA-gaphics, but still not so bad- Animations

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ah sweet sweet Kenshi, first off I want to point out I stole numerous copies of Kenshi before but in the end the game was so great(and had so many new bugfixes coming out) that I just had to buy it, so my gameplay time should be way way higher.  When I first played Kenshi the walls weren't in the game because they were to buggy, this was 2-3 years ago then im guessing, there was no background music in the game and a bunch of items didn't even have functioning icons but man was it great anyway.  Eventually I had to take a break for a while because a gamebreaking glitch where your characters take forever to respond to commands and then just stop responding.  But the glitch was repaired and they even came out with a whole new map for the world that looks just beautful instead of the rather barren one before.  Kenshi has a delightful limb damage system and a few dozen skills/attributes that all improve with use.  Kenshi has an easy to use base building system that allows you to set up basically anywhere.  This is one of the few alpha games that still seems truly unique every other major game has something a lot like it out or coming out as well but not Kenshi.  I haven't even tried out the new hunger system yet and I love survival aspects in games.  The only complaint I have right now is that the Slavers are like everywhere and if your team gets beaten in the start of the game looking to settle down theres a seemingly 25% chance you will all get picked up while knocked out and locked up.  The slavers seem to be a little too annoying at this point even on the easiest settings.  Oh and how could I forget the new races, they are awesome and unique and fit the feel so well, nice work on them.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Edit - Map is almost done! Such a great game. And now there has been a serious optimization upgrade. From 20-30 fps to 80-100.Edit - The map is expanding...the game keeps improving by leaps and bounds.Edit - Beta is out and man...it has gotten THAT much better.By an order of magnitude.The strangest, best, least, most RPG you will ever play.If you like free form games that allow your imagination to supply the details then this is the perfect game for you.Do you remember Daggerfall? There was a story, but it was easily ignored allowing you to do as you wished. It was the best sandbox a gamer could ask for in 1996. (I still have it)This is Daggerfall made by intention. There is no story...other than the one you supply.There are a few character types to choose from and that is it. You are plopped into a town with whatever cats (currency) and weapon the character had. No quest. You can stand there and watch the sun rise and set until you have logged 1,000 hours if you choose.Or...I trained on a fighting dummy for a month to improve my sword skills.I walked to a neighboring town some days away, avoiding the Dust Bandits along the way.I hired two mercs and took them to train with the dummy as I had.I looted a few unconscious people, and a couple of dead ones.I upset the local constabulary because I had looted one of them after they had been killed in an unrelated (to me, at least) battle. "Damned looters."I plan on building a town after I recruit more bodies. The history, the lore, the quests are all up to ME.One of the significant differences I have found is that although I save a lot (due to the early state of the game) I do not reload when something adverse occurs to my squad.I know that by combat itself my squad improves. The better the opponent the faster you learn defensive moves.We got jumped by some Sand Bandits and suffered wounds. In the run-of-the-mill RPG there is little benefit from suffering at all, so you reload. Replaying a particular battle over until you figure the puzzle out is frustrating and usually results in my abandoning a game.Not now. In fact, they are badges of pride. "Dude, we fought and won!"edit - I just beat the boss of a local bandit posse. He followed us, alone. I turned my crew and fought him 10:1. Yes, we won. Danged straight I am beaming. I thought his group of bandits would cower after seeing me holding his head but...I had to run to fight another day.I also am impressed with a dev that loves their game more than I do. It is a labor of love; it will continue at whatever pace Lo-Fi can afford.edit - Support is amazing. The Beta introduced some issues so the response was to issue a quick series of hotfixes. A game-breaking bug is reported, a game breaking bug is quashed 5 hrs later.This is the weirdest RPG that I love so much.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								      In this review we will go over a few of the key features along with the pros and cons of this game. I personally am at a stand point between loving the game and distaining it while keeping in mind the game is in alpha stage. I will explain if and why this game is worth the price.     This game has been in development since 2012, the development cycle has been slow, and an update roughly every two months at the time of this review (3/14/2014) the last known update was February 10th 2014. The game has a few of the features spoken of, the vast land scape that is truly every meaning of the word large. It would take you quite some time to get across the map, I clocked it at 24 minutes on standard speed (the game comes with three speed rates) There are a few things you can do at the beginning of each game, mostly attempt to trade with other factions or cities. As most factions are less than vanilla, the rewards are arguable. You could make a living hunting bandits, or you could simply create a single structure and have the bandits come to you (After maybe 3-4 hours of excessive training). Unless of course you would like to know how it feels to be a three legged cat chased by a pack of wolves. The fighting animations are fairly nice a few clashing of swords, however does get a bit repetitive which is fine considering the game is in alpha. Now there are other things you can work to accomplish if you actually want to feel some progression in the game, consider there is no story or dialogue to guide you in the game at this time  (3/14/2014). There is however a simple tutorial in the options menu. The base building of the game is fairly nice; you can make a nifty manufacturing system mine, research and build. Then find something else to do, which of course is all there is at this current state (which is fine) as the amount of time it takes to get to that point is quite hefty. The amount of available research is quite vast, which will take you at least six to nine hours, depending on which game speed you prefer. Once you have your super industrial enterprise and have the best warriors equipped with the best weaponry and training that the game allows the next step is to find something else to do. That can be a daunting task; you could put little outposts all over the map and make your own little empire with a few squad-mates. 	On another note, there are mods available for the game. The construction kit is easy to get. (http://kenshi.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Modding) Although, the amount of mods aren’t a huge attraction, but they do exist! Now then to pros of the game are. -Awesome concept.-Based on Sword fighting with nice animations. -Build a small empire.-Very large map.-Mod-ableNow for the cons.-Slow development.-Many game breaking bugs.(which is forgivable for an alpha of  course)-The game-play will come to a point where there isn’t much to do and wait for updates like many on the official forum.-The super crash (I clocked it at every 50 minutes) Quite a few of the fellow Kenshi players know what I am talking about.    The question you need to ask yourself before purchasing is the game worth the price tag (I picked the game up for 20 dollars). The developers do need the support I will not argue that, I merely want the buyer to understand what they are getting for their hard earned cash.  As of right now (3/14/2014) the reviews for the game are quite positive, especially from the players themselves and for good reason! The amount of potential for this game is beyond words. I am personally excited about the development, and so are many others. As a personal statement, please understand the game is in alpha stage with slow progression as most alpha stage games are just keep that in mind. If you are in doubt, watch some youtube videos on this game.       Referenceshttp://kenshi.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Moddinghttp://www.desura.com/games/kenshi/reviewshttp://www.indiegamemag.com/alone-no-more-kenshi-goes-the-crowdfunding-route/http://www.lofigames.com/index.php (this is their offical website.)


YouTube™ Video: Kenshi Alpha: Part 1- An Introduction to Kenshi! 

			Views: 15,319		

			Kenshi is a single player free-roaming Role Playing Game, with a Real-Time Strategy influence. Its squad-based, meaning you have a whole team of characters who can split up and go to different ends...

Early Access Review
								This Review will tell the story of my first 3 Charakters.The first one is short. I left the town and got beaten up by bandits.The second one took way longer but is as short to tell. I left the town and built a house. Then after watching my people working for about 20 min I got bored and started a new game.The third try I was exploring the world, hired a few followers and built another house. Then a single ninja walked by and killed all of my people.I see a lot of potential in this game. Right now it feels too easy to just roam the map, get rich, build an army and then a settlement. I expect that to change once needs like hunger are introduced and you need to get them covered. Also I miss a lot of RPG-content. But I trust the developers that they can deliver what they planned. The game right now is quite entertaining and once they do it will be near to infinite fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Epic, fun, impressive, and ready to play now.If you like free-roaming sandbox games with no level scaling and tons of base building options and exploration then this game is a must buy. There are no other games remotely like it that i'm aware of.I won't go into all the features but this game is rich and ready to play.  There are some large updates coming up so you can either resume playing or import everything into the new version depending if the update requires a new game.  Very impressed with being able to do the latter.Some other random good stuff:- The world seems plausible instead of a theme park like other games.- The dialogue is pretty good and funny.- You can fully automate your workers in your base(s) while you devote full-time to your exploration squad.- It's very challenging at first, it's fun getting past that hump and becoming strong.- Location damage is really cool, for instance if someone takes a hard blow to the stomach then they will be pressing on it with one of their hands until it's healed.- Combat is fun to watch as it's physics based animations.  If a blow is landed then you'll actually see the animation connect.- If you see something in a store inventory, then it's also stored somewhere in the shop physically that you can steal.Things I'd like to see:- Multi-threading and performance (coming very soon I believe)- Further help screens explaining some more of the game mechanics (how armor stacking works, damage reduction, etc.)- Audio improvements, especially combat- More of the map available- Notifications, for instance when one of your crafters's queue is empty and is idle.- Able to add notes to the world map- Underground structures to explore.  Like dungeons.- Traveling trader caravans.

Posted: October 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								oh my goosy moos this game is an endless sweet cake with the cherry on its head missing.this game is for everyone who loves endless sandbox gaming, a kinda post-apocalyptic world, rpgs, tycoonish management, craft and building things.+ not many bugs i encountered, I had one freeze and a certain group of paladins stuck in one area.+ even if the fights are mostly automatic, its always fun to watch getting your♥♥♥♥♥beaten+ style and art feels slick+ no crude hp bar, everyone has different bars how high the damage on your body parts are and combined with bloodloss gives you different ways how(long) are you knocked out and die.+ crafting is super fun, you can build your own base(s) and you can spend a lot of time+ gave me a lot of chuckles+ every success (mostly in battles) feels great in the hard environment+ I personally like the graphic, even if the shadows in some parts are kinda ♥♥♥♥ed up+ different choices how to start your game (be a starving injured poor guy, king , start with an legendary weapon and so on)+ sweet feature to queue tasks order to automate processes (like crafting, farming, etc)+ different races with differencies+ permadeath, which is not that easy to happen, since you a lot of factors need to happen~ optimisation, many slowdowns when shadows are activated in some parts, annihilating a lot of ram. but its already playable aside that~ AI behaving is mostly good, but some groups stuck in a certain area- the map is not comeplety accessable- its annoying when you cant click on certain areas, even if your group can walk through it (like up/downhills)- body parts are not able to chop off- would like to see some blood or gore- no gay marriage- would like to see more content and richness in overall ( but it its early access, so no drama)my conclusion: already a playable game, were you have enough content to waste a lot of time and having fun lying half dead on the ground

content:
Posted: April 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of the most ambitious games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. Kenshi is one of the reasons the gaming community will never stop dreaming, and will always have something to be excited about. It shows that one mans dream can become a reality as long as you stick to what you love. It also shows that you don't have to have millions of dollars and corporate funding to make a gem of an experience. Now on to the meat of the review. Kenshi has come a long way since I first bought it when it first came to steam. A lot of content and technological improvements has put more meat on it bones over time, however there are some bugs and a very steep learning curve and some people might get overwhelmed with the initial difficulty. The bugs come and go mostly except for some that have lingered on and have been a real issue for some people. Like the path finding and super crashes. These bugs usually flood in when a new update comes out and they get fixed relatively quickly as time goes on. The dev does a really good job at listening to his community and the moderators and players are generally helpful and will answer any questions you have about the game. There are tons of guides and YouTube videos so if you don't understand how to do something in  the game it's pretty easy to get an issue resolved or a question answered.This game offers many ways to play. You can be a trader, a bandit, a caravan guard, lone warrior/ wanderer, explorer, blacksmith, laborer, scientist, ninja, fragment axe wielding juggernaut. The list goes on and on, and the best thing about it is, more is going to be added in and you'll only have more ways to play the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Like sand? Who doesn't?Enjoy walking upon the countless ended lives of creatures that once were?Well Kenshi is the game for you!Start a game with some random scenario that you decide and get thrown into some random town, I got Capan.And now comes the biggest feature of the game: Learning Curve!!Wanna find a mission? Learning Curve!Wanna find someone to hire? Learning Curve!Wanna pick up that bounty? Learning Curve!Wanna turn that bounty in? Guess what ♥♥♥♥♥ - Learning Curve!that's right kids if walking on miles of the dead creatures doesn't tickle your pickle get ready for some good old fashion learning curves, joined a city but you don't know how to pay your taxes? Neither do I!Tried building your own town but your neighbors wont stop yelling at you to pay them or die? well tough♥♥♥♥♥♥Nancy that's Learning Curve!"This game is like 'Sims' for masochist and people who get overly aroused by ♥♥♥♥-tons of sand."And if any of your characters weight too much you're gonna wish that timer speed could go up to 11 for your face is going to be rocked with the seemingly endless amount of sand this game has to offer. And prepare to leave your slower friends to die as your inexperienced characters leave your heavy friend behind as that cannibal party comes charging from the sand dunes."Remember, I don't have to be faster than them, I just have to be faster than you."And for you gore fans out there be amazed and horrified as one of your characters gets their stomach ripped open and starts to bleed on the sand as the rest of your team undoubtedly get ripped to shreds by those damn Sand Ninja Jounin, believe it. Be amazed as said Jounin, after massacring your pathetically untrained party, starts to casually walk away and then sprints back as one of your surviving members recovers from their♥♥♥♥♥whooping just to have their head or arm cut off."It's like 'Desert Punk' the video game, but with more sand!"And if your the type of gamer who enjoys spending hours of time running [and pry to your gods not walking] from town to town in awe of the ridiculous amount of sand, this is the game for you!Ignore all of the bandits and buy trading goods and go from town to town trying to find the best price. buy and sale and become the wolf of sand-street as you flee from everyone who just wants to beat you up and leave you for dead. Because don't worry, they'll never steal your stuff, all they want to do is make sure you suffer and can't move.And you better believe they'll hunt you down until the end of the sands just to hurt you, hell they'll even run past city guards, run into the inn and attack you in your sleep, because ♥♥♥♥ you that's why.Over all if you want; Reality/Masochist 'Sims' with 'Desert Punk' meets medieval china all in the worlds largest sandy-box of ♥♥♥♥ you this game's for you!Did I mention there's a lot of sand?

								I love this game. I will in detial describe the good and the bad. But in my opinion the good FAR outweighs the bad here!First off the bad:Sometimes the ai gets stuck. Yes sometimes the ai will get stuck running between projects or delivery, towns, buildings or just plain start to stand there. But they know this and are constantly working hard trying to fix and update this.Sometimes buildings get a little buggy with placement of walls or and other "Shell building."Wall placement is a little... off... to be nice, sometimes bandits will walk right through/under a wall and attack you leaving you shaking your head after you kill them and figure out where in the world they came from!? They had no shovels on them so... there's that.Graphics are a slight eh. They are updating these as they have just switched to a x64 bit engine. (Yes they are still keeping x86 and DX9 so no worries about specs there)there are a few more oddities in this game, but those are the biggest.Next are my favorite things about this game:It lets you create your OWN tale! Whether you and your band of nomads roam place to place conquering and killing everything, which I might add, is harder than you think! Or perhaps a peaceful trader just trying to make an honest living out of your hard work, or otherwise ill gotten gains. But maybe, just maybe you are the daring settlers off to make your own mark on the world, or what's left of it, by building yourself a nice and cozy town amongst the barren wastes.Maybe become the dreaded sand ninjas/samurai/drifters/assassins of lore!!!You can create or destroy in life as in this game, the options are limitless... well as limited to your imagination and what the game has so far.In the future they will be adding slavery, ranged combat, robotics, new lands, and it all makes me excited just thinking of the new tales and stories to be had!In the end, I rate this 8.3/10 so far, and I am expecting a 87/100 finished. I set my expectations low as not to be dissapointed. Hope this helps!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's half finished, buggy and incredibly fun if you're into the RPG/simulator/strategy genre. It reminds me quite a bit of The Guild 2 (also sold here on Steam). It's a bit unstable. I crash about every 2-3 hoursI made character, picked the origin where you start with a broken arm and a stick in the middle of nowhere. I was the gimpies gimp that have ever gimped. Knowing what to expect from reading other reviews I looked at my map and headed for the nearest town. As expected my crippled self attracted the attention of some bandits on the way. Knowing that fighting them would be brief and pointless I just kept running (bravely) away. Made it to a town and hid. The town guards dispatched the bandits. When it was safe I sauntered back out and started looting, making several trips to the local shops. After I had confiscated all the bandit possesions and profited I headed to the nearest tavern and recruited some backup. I could now confiscate things twice as fast! And that's pretty much how things went for a while. Traveling from town to town, luring bandits along into town guard ambushes, recruiting more and more people. Invested in some backpacks. I even started getting a little bolder and would help the townguards with dispatching these outlaws. My people would get hurt and sometimes even knocked out but I always made sure everyone had first aid kits on them, ready to patch a fallen friend up.  Before I knew it I was leading a group of 20 people, 18 females and 2 males (amazons!),  and we could actually kill single groups of bandits alone without the help of town guards.  It was time to build an outpost!Outpost life is hard. Not a day goes by without getting hassled by bandits, ninjas or cannibals. It didn't take long before I decided to pay the Dust Bandit faction off to leave me alone. One payment and they havent bothered me since. That cut the constand hassling down to about half and made it manageble. I can usually handle any town ambushes but I do sometimes get overrun and have to make a run for it to the closest town (Brink). But I finally finished the wall surrounding my outpost and my little group gets stronger every day!

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Like sand? Who doesn't?Enjoy walking upon the countless ended lives of creatures that once were?Well Kenshi is the game for you!Start a game with some random scenario that you decide and get thrown into some random town, I got Capan.And now comes the biggest feature of the game: Learning Curve!!Wanna find a mission? Learning Curve!Wanna find someone to hire? Learning Curve!Wanna pick up that bounty? Learning Curve!Wanna turn that bounty in? Guess what ♥♥♥♥♥ - Learning Curve!that's right kids if walking on miles of the dead creatures doesn't tickle your pickle get ready for some good old fashion learning curves, joined a city but you don't know how to pay your taxes? Neither do I!Tried building your own town but your neighbors wont stop yelling at you to pay them or die? well tough♥♥♥♥♥♥Nancy that's Learning Curve!"This game is like 'Sims' for masochist and people who get overly aroused by ♥♥♥♥-tons of sand."And if any of your characters weight too much you're gonna wish that timer speed could go up to 11 for your face is going to be rocked with the seemingly endless amount of sand this game has to offer. And prepare to leave your slower friends to die as your inexperienced characters leave your heavy friend behind as that cannibal party comes charging from the sand dunes."Remember, I don't have to be faster than them, I just have to be faster than you."And for you gore fans out there be amazed and horrified as one of your characters gets their stomach ripped open and starts to bleed on the sand as the rest of your team undoubtedly get ripped to shreds by those damn Sand Ninja Jounin, believe it. Be amazed as said Jounin, after massacring your pathetically untrained party, starts to casually walk away and then sprints back as one of your surviving members recovers from their♥♥♥♥♥whooping just to have their head or arm cut off."It's like 'Desert Punk' the video game, but with more sand!"And if your the type of gamer who enjoys spending hours of time running [and pry to your gods not walking] from town to town in awe of the ridiculous amount of sand, this is the game for you!Ignore all of the bandits and buy trading goods and go from town to town trying to find the best price. buy and sale and become the wolf of sand-street as you flee from everyone who just wants to beat you up and leave you for dead. Because don't worry, they'll never steal your stuff, all they want to do is make sure you suffer and can't move.And you better believe they'll hunt you down until the end of the sands just to hurt you, hell they'll even run past city guards, run into the inn and attack you in your sleep, because ♥♥♥♥ you that's why.Over all if you want; Reality/Masochist 'Sims' with 'Desert Punk' meets medieval china all in the worlds largest sandy-box of ♥♥♥♥ you this game's for you!Did I mention there's a lot of sand?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm writing this during the Alpha 0.62 phase of development. Positives:Self-set goalsInteresting worldEpic mass battlesA wide range of gameplay optionsDetailed battle system and character creationNegatives:Self-set goalsMany bugs (for now)A lot of patience requiredvisually bland environment (endless desert)I got this game as soon as it was released on steam and I can say that it is absolutely fun to play. It has plenty of bugs (for now) and there are many unfinished aspects of the game but that is alright. Whatever this game is lacking right now it makes up for in excess with its gameplay. You do not start strong and there is nothing designed to be "easy." In fact, you will get demolished by anybody at the start of the game. The real fun for me came from building up my squad (I started with two characters, i now have 20) creating a town of my own, and then using my expanding reserves of money, skilled fighters, and tradesmen to utterly dominate anyone who crossed my path. Be warned though, because of the nature of this game it takes a LOT of patience. If you are able to strive through that though then it will be both extremely rewarding and enjoyable for you. I expect many great things as time goes on and can't wait to see the new game dynamics which will make this even better in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of the most ambitious games I've ever had the pleasure of playing. Kenshi is one of the reasons the gaming community will never stop dreaming, and will always have something to be excited about. It shows that one mans dream can become a reality as long as you stick to what you love. It also shows that you don't have to have millions of dollars and corporate funding to make a gem of an experience. Now on to the meat of the review. Kenshi has come a long way since I first bought it when it first came to steam. A lot of content and technological improvements has put more meat on it bones over time, however there are some bugs and a very steep learning curve and some people might get overwhelmed with the initial difficulty. The bugs come and go mostly except for some that have lingered on and have been a real issue for some people. Like the path finding and super crashes. These bugs usually flood in when a new update comes out and they get fixed relatively quickly as time goes on. The dev does a really good job at listening to his community and the moderators and players are generally helpful and will answer any questions you have about the game. There are tons of guides and YouTube videos so if you don't understand how to do something in  the game it's pretty easy to get an issue resolved or a question answered.This game offers many ways to play. You can be a trader, a bandit, a caravan guard, lone warrior/ wanderer, explorer, blacksmith, laborer, scientist, ninja, fragment axe wielding juggernaut. The list goes on and on, and the best thing about it is, more is going to be added in and you'll only have more ways to play the game.

Leave the town with a big grin on my face.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm changing my review from a negative one to a positive one. There's just too much potential and fun in this game to hate on it. It has camera control issues, lag, and sometimes incredibly frustrating pathing issues, but I found that cranking down the graphics settings helped with some of those problems. With a great mod that increased the population limit and squad size, I've been having a lot of fun establishing bases and sending out parties to explore. If this game ever reaches completion (the full map accessible, some of the mechanics fixed - i.e. kidnapping/stealth kill which doesn't seem to work) this game will be incredible. In my opinion it's a better Fallout than Fallout - if you don't mind some beta flaws.Holy ♥♥♥♥ the pathing issues tho - those seriously need to be fixed.

content:

Early Access Review
								This is a very in depth, fun game. You travel the world, recruiting other people to help you in your adventure. It's difficult to survive. I've been killed countless times because I enter a wrong building. Once you get set up and establish a decent sized village, the game gets a little easier. It's still being developed. I enjoy it so far. The difficulty makes it an enjoyable experience once you start to build a community. You have to research everything, practice skills for tremendous amounts of time and then hope you don't get mauled by some ridiculous creature while exploring and trying to expand your knowledge/resources/skill set.I would buy this game again without hesitation. I reccomend it for anyone who enjoys challenging RPG style gameplay in an enormous open world.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is great, even in it's early stage. The fact that you have many start options is amazing, very few games will give you this opportunity. I must admit i started at least 20 games... At first, the Freedom Seekers, a group of 7 people with a very good stack of building materials is tempting. So you can build a farm or mine very fast. In the long run, i decided to start solo, with the trader, no cash but what you have in your backpack is enough to get you started. If you're brand new to this, google a guide for beginner, believe me, it helps... As i said previously, it's in an early stage, so you will encounter some bugs... Thank god you haven't deselect the auto-save which will save you're skin many times, believe me. The producer is updating regularly so if you encounter some new bugs, like i did, it's fixed in no time. So, overall, all good except for the camera style... I can't adjust myself to click on the middle-mouse button to rotate camera, and for some reason the camera system is only for top-bottom activity, so if you're heading to a city that's up to a moutain, you can't see it until you're almost in it, as if you were trying to see a bird in the sky, it's only top-bottom, that's mainly the only problem i see on the current version of this amazing game... Enjoy!

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								A lot of people worry about buying Early Access games. And they should. Early Access is a risky investment for the consumer. But you don't need to worry about this developer. This is a solid team making a great game. I've had it several years now. It started off rough around the edges, buggy, unstable, but fun. I had a lot of fun in its early stages. Its a testament to the core aspects of the game that I loved it even with its Pre-Alpha quirks. It pre dates Early Access on Steam altogether. After all this time. The original lone developer, Chris, (and now a complete team) made something really special. Its got a ways to go. But it has grown exponentially since when I bought it even.I bought it just after they added sound to the game. I want to say that was 2012 but I don't quite remember. I had my eye on it prior to that but that is when I took the plunge. I started off confused. I wasn't really sure how the game worked. The style was nice but the world was a little off in the ways that any game is prior to an alpha release. Despite that, I had a great time. Its fun just roaming a desert. Its fun talking to the weird inhabitants.  It was awesome when I finally WON a fight. And base building is as fun as it is time consuming.I was running from city to city, gathering resources, gaining a comrade or two in the process. Booking it past Bandits and Ninjas to the safety of city. And, once I was strong enough, fighting back, with mixed results. It is interesting that the sense of relief I feel when my limping character carries a bleeding out comrade to the safety of city walls... is immediately followed by the desire to venture outside of those walls yet again. Thats Kenshi for you. Its all in the goals you set for yourself. The original map was a massive desert. Fun but monotonous. The new map adds quite a bit of spice to that. Swamps. Fog Islands, Coastal areas, Forests, Mountains, and a new and improved desert. More is to come. Only half of the map is available at the moment, but it is huge. I'm not even close to discovering all the major cities and I have put 20 hours this week on exploring it (and that is all I have been doing with my squad)First the danger outside of those walls was Ninjas and Bandits. New updates added Cannibals, wildlife... fog men. There are hostile areas (particularly in the North) you should back off from unless you have a group of solid fighters. Either the enemy's numbers or skill will overwhelm a new player there. I really enjoy the creature design. Familiar creatures exist like dogs, bulls, turtles and then there are Garrus, Beak Things, and some creatures that should be avoided altogether because they are four stories tall. Its a journey for your squad and its a personal thing, because the game doesn't tell you where to go. It doesn't tell you to stop until all of your guys are dead. It just says, "GO." From a guy with a sword to an impressive company of nomadic traders. From a crippled old man stranded in the desert to builder of a city. An escaped slave to the conqueror of an empire.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I haven't seen a game with more raw potential  this early since... well, ever. It's already an addicting timesink, and I can only imagine it'll get even better as time goes on. I love the RTS/Open-World RPG hybrid idea. Base building, squad management, character progression, and a huge world full of warring factions. This seems like one of those dream-games that people were trying to build decades ago before the technology existed and the industry got caught up in multimillion dollar AAA ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The aesthetic is wonderful. "Steampunk Samurai Western." That is now officially my favorite combination of words.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game can be described as Skyrim meets town building.I think the beauty of it is probably the early game struggle whether you're playing a single warrior or a weak bunch of settlers... in both experiences you'll only just be barely surviving and it's that edge of your seat moment to moment that makes the game so addicting. Yes in time you will become a master but it does the early game better than other survival rpgs in the genre. You will come to care about your characters if only due to all the extreme close calls you've been through with them.If you can imagine your most ideal open sandbox game lacking only a well written story or deep characters, well that's Kenshi.It does go from being one of the best games I've played to being a painful bug-ridden headache. But the Dev is very active adding a lot of new content quickly and likewise trying to fix bugs just as fast. I have a lot of faith in the Dev and the beautiful game he's creating and know it will be a labor of love that only continues to get better over the years.The highs for me overcome the lows. I'd recommend playing, it will be a game you remember fondly for a long time to come - provided you're lucky enough to have your first playthrough be a stable experience :)

content:
Posted: February 24
Early Access Review
								I Love the idea of this game and have put about 90 hours into it.  I believe in being honest so here is the good and the bad.First the bad, the game lags quite a bit if you don't lower view distances even with an I7-6900K, 64GB ram, 1080 video card, 3 SSD raid 0.  In other words a pretty decent gaming rig.  In order to get it to a playable state I had to drastically reduce viewing distances, turn off shadows, reflections etc....  I am able to play in the correct resolution for my monitor 3440x1440 but I had to turn most options fairly low before it was in a playable state.  Game is still in Alpha apparently, so may be this will be worked on and get corrected in the future through some sort of optimization.  Now for some of the good things about this game!  Character customization is superb, you can drastically change the way your toon looks when getting setup.  The devs have made massive updates to the game content wise since I first started playing it.  The game world looks substantially better than it used too in almost every single way imaginable.  I am not saying the graphics are F'ing amazing or something but they have improved and the world is not nearly as boring as it once was visually.Long story short it is a good indie title and definitely enjoyable if you have some patience.  Just remember your character sucks badly when you start and your best bet is running from danger to begin with.  You characters improve steadily through harvesting, fighting, running, carrying heavy objects, manufacturing etc... etc... if you like the idea of a squad based sandbox game with no real end game goal this could help you kill many an hour of boredom.

content:
Posted: March 24
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a game you can casually play for a few hours and be done with it, you should not buy Kenshi. This game takes a lot of time to get almost anything done. The huge world alone (and not even all of it is playable at this point) takes hours to explore, especially if you dont want your characters to starve on the way. The different zones make the world feel interesting enough, even though there are a lot of huge open spaces (perfectly suited to start a base).There are a lot of different ways you can play this game:Build a base with everything you need protected by a huge wall strong enough to withstand groups of raiders... orGather a few capable fighters to pillage camps, raider groups and whole cities if you are up to it... orMove swiftly in the shadows while you steal the most expensive goods to sell in another city where nobody knows (or cares) that the goods were stolen in the first place.But no matter what you do, be prepared to lose fights and almost get killed or enslaved over and over again, until you are an experienced survivor, because the start is very rough and the first few hours you will probably barely hang on to your life. But keep going, because once your stats allow you to withstand a proper fight, it will be so rewarding to pay back the beating.All in all this game has already very deep and intriguing mechanics and no matter what play style you choose, there is enough content to keep you busy for days. The development seems slow at first, but whenever there is a content update, it is usually pretty profound. The game is still a little glitchy, but there have been big improvements over the last year, so apart from occasional reloading, the bugs are not really much of a problem anymore.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								I remember seeing this game a couple years ago and being genuinely interested. I had a He-Man Lunchbox for a rig back then, so I figured it wouldn't run and held off on the purchase. Fast forward to my current rig, and now I still can't run it at max. But even with choppy frames it held my interest.The open world of Kenshi gives you an interesting post-post-apocalyptic backdrop where death is a constant threat, but survival is rewarded. Next to nothing remains of the old world, and there's been too many generations since for anyone to remember it or even know about it. The desert sands have left only unrecognisable hulking metal structures for scavengers to gather scrap iron, and the technologies of the past are only hinted about in tattered books that are sold at high prices. A fanatical religion dabbling in feudalism controls most cities and outposts, but searching beyond their military's grasp will find you in stranger places and their people, where you might find reward or a desolate death.In Kenshi, the player's role in the world is never specified. Your actions are completely free to you, but the world does react to them. What sets it apart from other sandbox is that NPC's can perform the same actions as you. Bandits will loot you after knocking you out, and factions may send trader's if your shop interests them. When you're researching walls and farming techniques, NPC outposts are studying the same, if not better, technologies. The Kenshi world is truly large, and set to be even bigger with future updates. There's nothing else really like Kenshi in similar genre's, and it's a truly ambitious idea. Only regret is not buying it earlier.

								I just want to say that this game is pretty incredible for what it's worth. Beign a video game design student that is focusing on audio and visuals, the soundtrack sets the tone and just gives me chills. Gameplay reminds me of Baldur's Gate in a sense, with the stop starting squad movements.Overall, quite an amazing game well worth its price. I would very much like to see what the devs come out with next. 5/7

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								My take on Kenshi is a mixed bag.  Bottom line is I love the game but it's horrendously buggy and development is extremely slow.They bill it as an RPG with RTS elements, but it doesn't play that way for me.  I see it more as an RTS with RPG elements.  You scavenge materials, build a base, train recruits and laborers and defend or go on the aggressive.  It reminds me a bit of Earth 2150 in how each unit can earn experience and lvl up (the RPG aspects) while maintaining an RTS-like squad-focused feel.It's a lot of fun training your troops and building your town up.  But the bugs, oh my.  If you play the "stable" release, expect to crash randomly every hour or so like clockwork.  I honestly had better stability with the "experimental" opt-in steam beta branch, however some friends with similar rigs say they can't play the experimental version at all due to single digit frame-rates (it plays fine for me).  But either way you go, the sad state of pathing AI in this game really kills the joy.  Regular reloads when your own guys get stuck in the landscape and terrain and a constant spectacle of enemy units stuck on hills and corners.   This is by far the worst of the bugs, but there are lots of others.I really like the game and think it has awesome potential, but the state of development and the persistence of bugs through so many releases really has me discouraged.If you managed to pick it up on sale like I did and don't mind risking a small investment on a game with great potential, then go for it.  If you aren't willing to throw money at a project that may never be completed and has too many bugs to enjoy for any length of time in it's current state, then I suggest you wait and see what happens.  For me, I'd do it again.  I knew what I was getting into and the sale price of $10 makes it an acceptable risk.

								The most important thing first off to mention is it's an early access game. it is by no means complete, and if you choose to buy it keep that in mind. However, I myself bought it when it was $15, and really after playing it for so long and getting so much out of it when it is not even close to complete I would have been willing to pay much more than that. This is a masterpiece in the works, and is well on its way. The only complaint I can make is the updates are fairly spaced out, but this is very understandable because of the type of game this is and the size of the development team. If anything they are fairly sporadic in their updates all considered.If you like the idea of building a city/army/both, or strategy games in general, this is for sure the game for you and I recommend buying it as soon as possible not only to support the developers in their endeavors but also to experience the greatness.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								First of all, my playtime is not accurate as I bought Kenshi well before it was available on Steam. Just want to add my thoughts about the dev cycle of this game. I rarely buy games before their full release given the risks of doing so. In the past years I have seen the dev team for this game go from basically one person's passion project to something more likely to be able to provide the grand vision the dev has. I have to say I have been impressed with this dev's committment to this title, even after making a good deal of pre-order/beta sales over the years. Integrity is important, and in my view this dev has done a good job working consistently to live up to his promises during this time. If watching a passion project game slowly grow is something you can be patient and handle, Kenshi is worth the ask price.tl;dr I do not regret buying this title years ago pre-steam. Would buy again. High-integrity Dev

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								A one of it's kind genre of a game. Open World RTS RPG ect ect. The work on the game is quite fast (considering the features added all the time) and was slowed down by a huge amount of work on Pathfinding, which is finally done. In the meantime, they've been adding animals, random insult generator, and all sorts of fun stuff to their dev build in preparation for the finished pathfinding. I found the game fun back in the earliest stages of alpha, without sound, great graphics, or any polish at all. It was buggy but fun then, now the bugs are fewer and the fun is far greater.The limitations for the game are slowly getting reversed, and the game is becoming more grand by the day, with lots of dev updates and supports. The community is still small, meaning it's a lot easier to get a message across to the devs if you are feeling concerned. Overall, this is my all time favorite strategy game, start the game with a stick and become a martial arts master who runs a fortress with well armed squad of companions who tear up all sorts of bandit life in the wastelands.The game is great, but it's only gonna get better from here!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								my my where to begin... this game is over 9000% early access (strange bugs, horrible pathfinding, very little variety in anything, very few updates, so many unexplained crashes) and yet... it appeals to me like very few other games have. i mean when you first jump in the game is hard as diamond and as rough as sharks skin and more brutal than dark souls but i think it really sets the mood.the game takes place on some sort of desert planet full of bandit groups, thugs for higher and shabby towns. its survival of the fittest and you better hope you and your crew are fit to survive.Pros:-completely open ended gameplay (you want to murder and cage every npc in a particular town? if your characters are strong enough then by all means!)-super in depth damage system (some bandit breaks both your legs? prepare to crawl on home boy, and pray that you don't lose em!)-build your own town/outpost (for training, crafting, and trading)-lots of crafting to be done-super in depth character creation (can also be used on newly recruited characters)-indication on the hud on who is being aggroed allows the easy snapping to any battle situation no matter what you are doing with verry little load time (like if you have 3 units running weapons to a nearby town for trading when suddenly a group of bandits shows up to your town)cons:-some structures can not be deleted-its not entirely clear whether or not your machines are not working because you don't have any power or they are full of junk at first glance-some of the UI is cut off-fast forward not fast enough (i don't want to watch my guy with broken legs carrying tons of stuff and an unconscious ally inch along the barren desert for hours looking for a town with a bed)-beds are easily exploitable     -if you have no cash or the bed is not public you can just pick someone up and lay them on the bed and it just works        -you can place NPCs with bounties who are "dying" in beds to prevent them from kicking the bucket and as an added bonus they also won't take any♥♥♥♥♥♥from guards who will be aggroed on them until they are removed from the bed(s)-very peculiar bugs (one that comes to mind is my armor smith somehow getting a stack of 40000 iron plates and another stack of the same size in the container i was keeping them in when he only had time to make 40 or so of them and his AI constantly taking way more that the armor making station can hold and stopping work on armor production as a result)-SUPER ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PATHFINDING!- one of the towns has 2 gates however one of them is blocked by a poorly made hill or something and the pathfinding dictates that they exit the other gate and go all the way around the outer town wall just to get to where they are going.-super steep learning curve-amazingly slow pace-HaVOK physics engine makes ragdolls look silly (even the dev made fun of it on twitter)-strange bugs with carrying people some distance and later dropping them-job allocation not clear enough (and for the longest time i didn't even know it was a thing making for a lot of tedious micro management)if you don't mind bugs and don't have interest in any finished games at the moment: get itif you do mind bugs or are looking at other games that are complete: go get those other games! its early access (at the time of writing this its actually in alpha) its not done and many of the cons i listed may be fixed by the time it actually comes out. so for you guys i would just wait until then.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have played over 40 hours and so far I had a nice ride. Here´s my review:good graphics and setup. the character design and customization is neat, although I played zoomed out most of the time anyways. nice ideas and gameplay when it comes to base building and crafting. pretty good production chains. very nice concepts in this game. I love the post-apocalyptic-style of world design. atmoshpere-wise this really stand out.BUT... and there´s always a but it seems:( i know it´s early access , I get it. I never expected a finished game. it´s not that I bught it without having experience with other EA titles.)1. core mechanics not working or not working consistently enoughthis one is my main concern. workers forget their jobs, which means you end up a lot of micromanaging individual group members. also pathfinding and collision is a mess sometimes. even the workaround (which are offered, that´s a plus) don´t work consistently2. slow development cycles. the game is in development, which is nice. but so far I have experienced only one real update. the devs are in contact with the playersm which is nice. but I wonder how this game will ever pick up some momentum and gain some ground. basically from my standpoint, i couldn´t care less about great char graphics and player customization... thats all icing on the cake once its baked and finished to eat. but pathing, collision and AI behaviour is so essential for this kind of game that it needs to get taken care of asap. and when  Í read on the forums that some core game bugs are dependent on the actual game engine chosen for the game, I am prone to believe that maybe the have chosen the wrong engine....its been a good expense/reward scenario for me. I don´t mind spending the money as the time I played was great. but there´s no poin fo rme in keeping playing right now, because of the points mentioned before. keep in mind: it´s early access. so if you want to support the game and idea behind it (like I wanted to):buy it. its a good investment as the game itself will be sweet once it´s far more advanced. whenever that might be though...

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update 10/07/15Kenshi has gone through a massive bug bash and is now far more playable than ever before. It is still missing the complete world map and still needs more content, but the majority of the bugs i mentioned in my review are now squashed! Kenshi has all the potential to be a great game, possibly even Warband great.At the moment it is fun but with no real longevity and a lot of bugs. This is to be expected in any Early Access game and as more content is added and the bugs are slowly squashed the game will only get better.Pros* A different play style - the world is cruel and you are but a grape waiting to be stamped on. (being beaten to a pulp by a group of starving homeless people with sticks, wearing pajamas is a cruel start to any game.)* Excellent damage system - limb damage and animations.* Base building (leads to CTD's at the moment but you can still experiment.)* The beginnings of an economy, with many items to purchase, craft and sell. (selling is a little bugged and not fully implemented yet.)* Open sandbox world - with the promise of many more biomes to come (currently there is only one flavor, desert!)Cons* Bugs glorious bugs! - CTD's every hour or so in the stable version, less to none with experimental, but a boat load of others such as NPC's getting stuck everywhere.* Without quests, faction relations and other planned features the game can get a little repetitive after 4-6hrs. (you will need to create your own adventure.)* Thrown in at the deep end - steep learning curve (can also be seen as a pro!)* Slow developmentMy main issue with Kenshi, and i believe the only reason you should not buy it if you like this type of game is the slow development speed. I cope with this because i really do believe in the devs and understand that this was a 1 man show for a long time and that this is their 1st project together. Everyone has to start somewhere! But because of this big bugs, such as the memory leaks and pathfinding are taking a long time to squash!So, should you buy Kenshi? If you like open world RPG squad management games... then it all depends how patient you are..... if you are not, then i would wait, there is an option on the Kenshi website to receive an email when the game is fully released.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll write a short tale on how I became Hitler of Kenshi, the human experimenter.My journey began in wanting to be the world's greatest swordsman. So naturally I studied how to increase my combat skills. It says in the description of leveling up your combat skills, such as katana, dexterity, offense, and defence to fight stronger opponents than you in order to gain a bonus in leveling them. But, the obvious problem to that is when fighting stronger opponents you run a very high risk of dying. So I took on a passive approach. In the beginning I aggroed stronger mobs into friendly cities in order to maybe get a hit in between the crossfire. After the fighting was over I looted and bandaged the mob. Then I realised something, if the mob were not armed (because I looted them) they cannot fight back. Thus I learned a faster method to grinding my skills. Every once in a while I would get hurt so I ran to the local inn and rested my injuries. There I wondered, if I can rest my body faster this way, can I rest the bad guy's bodies? Of course I can. So I started making a human farm of looted enemies where I would beat them to unconsciousness, put them on a bed, then beat them to unconsciousness when they got better. But, the story doesn't end here. Later when I was building my village I noticed I can construct prison cages. What originally started out as a simple outpost for researching weapon crafting, turned into a human livestock factory of caged samurais and holy paladins where they would be beaten to unconsciousness every momment they are awake.tldr: I made a post-apocalyptic japanese concentration camp.9/10 (1- for the damn glitches, go finish the game)

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								I gave this game a negative review about a year ago. The reason for that was at the time, the game had stuff to do but doing any of it required you to travel across a vast and featureless desert. I played for two hours and most of that time was spent doing almost literally nothing. It was a slog. I didn't mind the difficult and unforgiving combat, and the lack of ranged options only put me off mildly. It was that wide open desert, that vast expanse of nothingness seperating all that juicy interesting content.I noticed Kenshi in my library recently, and knowing well that it's developer was dedicated to making this game, I clicked it to see what had changed in the last year between now and when I had written that first review. As a friend of mine said, Development had gone from slow to frantic in that space of time. The old boring map was scrapped in favor of a far more interesting landscape. I installed the game and upon booting and making my character, my eyes were met with far more than brown sand and nothingness. The landscape is clearly still a wasteland, but it is now filled with interesting flora and fauna, and dotted with the twisted metal wreckage of some long gone peoples. I actually WANT to see this new world that Kenshi's creator has put foreward. That alone is enough for me to turn a thumbs down into a thumbs up. Apart from that, the game also features several races and female characters now. Sneaking and theft are a thing. Ranged combat is still not planned except for as mounted crossbow emplacements, which irks me a bit but not badly. Some of the stuff I didn't get to see before has become more accessable thanks in part to a landscape which isn't ballachingly tedious and boring to cross. The UI is also a lot more attractive and fitting.As a final note from my new experiance with Kenshi, I entered a town and immediately some preist told me I was a ♥♥♥♥♥ and needed to repent the darkness in my heart. Also, Someone shouted that some bandit nearby was "possessed by skeletons!" I know that one of the races is called "skeletons" but at the same time, I find the concept very funny.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
KenshiI will start by giving a brief history of my experience with Kenshi....When I first seen this game I was ecstatic, I felt like finally an rpg like sandbox/simulation game was being developed that had a theme which I found fitting and unique. It came across as something being built upon and in a very ambitious manner. When I first jumped in kenshi I did not have much to work with other than running from town to town across this expansive desert or farming hemp. NPCs were pretty rare at this point and it did not matter much to me. I still found myself running around aimlessly, having fun just imaging what this game can eventually turn out to be. I truly believe this game has nigh endless possibility for the fans out there of this style of game play.I have to say all in all this game is pretty self explanatory from the trailer. You can choose several starts for your character, all of which give you a different style of game play starting from a solo rp play style to a squad based one. (you can start with 1 pc or 5, you can start as a trader or retired soldier) When you get in after creating your PC you are given a rough ui with all the controls laid out in a help screen. Forewarning this is not a walk in the park, expect your survivability to be low especially when picking a tougher starting.However, regardless of what start you end up picking you will most likly be forced to do a few monotonous things to survive. Such as having hostile npcs chase you into town, staying alive while the guards kill said hostile npcs and then looting/selling the gear you recover from them. Admittedly this is an issue, one I see being resolved as the skill and stat system is fleshed out more. Albeit I feel as of right now, in the stage this game is currently in (alpha) it would not appeal to someone lacking the needed patience or interest in Kenshi's development. IMO - I am willing to wait as long as it takes to see this game reach it's full potential. A project of this magnitude takes time, and I hope the devs keep updating it with the slow and steady approach. This means working updates that actually change major aspects of the games mechanics, graphics, ai, landscapes...I think I have seen these guys rework or update about almost everything this game has to offer since initial release.  UpdatesIf you have any doubts about this game seeing updates, I would ask you to consider the following. I have been following Kenshi closely for some time and the developers are making a fantastic effort with updates. I have about 60 hrs so far putting in a few every other week since initial release. I can say the changes this game has undergone is tremendous. Here you can find any info regarding updates and the roadmap[www.lofigames.com]Be patient and take solace in knowing you will be supporting something that does take great effort to create. The team for Kenshi is not all that lucrative afaik and the amount of work I personally have seen put in at this stage is well worth the current price tag. Pros vs Cons(All subject to personal preference)  Pros Cons   Price Tag Very Long Devel Stages   Endless Possibility/Modding Support A lot of monotony in this stage/Very Long Devel Stages   Major bugs are hot fixed fast You Can Find A lot of bugs   Time Consuming Time Consuming Short of the developers studio being swallowed whole by the earth itself or losing all funding...I don't see this one not living up to it's potential. With the extent of this games mechanics and the capability of a modding community, the sky is the limit for this one. Another game that will surely, one day become a classic among the host of others.Recommended

content:
Posted: April 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of the few early access titles I've not regretted picking up early. It delievers a decent level of content already with a lot more promised on the horizon, and it actually abides by the spirit of what early access is rather than just being a sort of super early preorder; the developer actually uses community feedback to determine what features to focus on.The game itself is also very engaging, but that's more a matter of personal preference. At its core it's primarily a sandbox game (and as far as I'm aware the first sandbox game to feature primarily desert, which strikes me as odd; think of the symbolism!), though at the moment it isn't as flexible as you'd expect a sandbox game to be. Even in early access, however, there is a decent level of easily accessible moddibility to be found. You can tweak and create weapons, NPCs, characters and even build NPC towns and modify the base mechanics of the game with a simple and relatively straightforward GUI.There is unfortunately not much more to say about the game at this stage because it is still early access and seemingly a long way off from release, which may be enough to put a lot of people off. Let me repeat because it can't be overstated: this game is made by an incredibly small team (it was a team of one for a long time) and it isn't likely to be finished in 2014, maybe not even in 2015. But it's already a fun game at its core if you like squad based RPGs or town building simulators or a mix of both, and it is steadily progressing. I also expect that over the coming year it'll start seeing some decent modding.

Early Access Review
								To preface this review I would like to say,  "I really did not want to rate this game negativly. I also understand the early access stance of the game" It has a bold and unique style. And presents great "Potential" for gameplay. Many systems are implimented and more will be added. The game handles adventure and  the life of a wonder very well. These aspects will get even better with the new map. This is were my issue with the developers priorities come in. Far more resources need to go to bug fixing at the moment before adding new content. The second you start trying to build any mildly complicated base you will be in micro managing hell. Characters commonly get stuck  when depositing items into storage, get stuck under the stairs of buildings, randomly get their position confused and think they are outside a gate (this one is a little wierd), characters fill their inventories with♥♥♥♥♥♥when the container they are trying to hall to is full (I could probably fix this one if given access to the code. Check if their is space to stire the item in before allowing a character to pick up items from the original container. Items currently being hauled there by any any other character assigned to the task of auto hauling are counted into this total as well. They would still have issues if the player fills the container they are going to manually, but it is a start.), river raptors congregating at the base door and glitching through. Most of the issues involving characters being stuck can be fixed by reloading saving and loading the game. Until the game crashes as a result of this.

								A very fun and addictive game a cross between stratergy and survival game genre. You can choose diffrent sceneries to start your story all of which add diffrent difficulties and fun to the game for example one spawns you in the middle of a camp of cannibils in which your be knocked out and have to escape, Another starts you off with a bunch of freedom seekers wanting to start their own town with a few supplies to get you started. 								This game has improved dramatically since I first purchased it back in 2013.  It still has a ways to go to be a finished product, but is playable and extremely fun in the current experimental branch. I would recommend this game to any one that enjoys games like xcom or the Total War series of games. The game features town building, tech research, farming, mining, smithing, squad building and lots of exploration and fighting.  There also seems to be a growing mod community for the game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update: April 6, 2016The Beta landed on 4-1-16 (EST) and already there have been no less than nine (9) hotfixes. The map is long and dark and full of mystery. All of the game mechanics are being refined. I know it seems to be a bit assholish to declare one's self correct, but, I was right about this one. Kenshi is an absolute joy, even when it is killing me. Its difficult nature lends to its developing world. Its unforgiving nature challenges the Player in ways that almost make her quit. Yet, she can't. Because the world of Kenshi is so beautiful and full of challenge. I highly recommend this game.Update: March 31, 2016Gotta say, I am super psyched for the beta release that is incoming. I have logged at least 150 hours since I wrote about my initial reaction to the thing that is Kenshi. I say 'thing' because this game is quite unlike anything I have ever played before. Yet, it is something I have always wanted as a gamer ever since I can remember.It scratches an itch that I've had for years. It combines sand box with squads and squads with player characters. It merges tower defense with  world domination. Troop dispositions and enemy  patrols so seamless, you might have died and gone to Heaven. But no. There is no Heaven in Kenshi. You could build a haven though, if you live long enough...There are strange beasts that roam the lands, looking only to pick off your weakest squad member. Leviathans prowl the dunes searching for... I don't know what... Best hope your haven isn't in their path.There are roving bands of dispicable men who would surely cut your throat as soon as rob you.There are strange tribes of what once were people who seek only to sate their hunger in this wasteland. I have grown used to dealing with the Cannibals, but, I wonder what brings them this far South? A lack of meat, maybe. Or perhaps they wish to test me and mine's swords...The Lo-Fi folks have lovingly and diligently crafted an amazing game. I have had a ton of fun playing it over the years. Yes, development has been "slow". But, damn if it didn't develop!!!I wish nothing but the best for Lo-Fi and thank them for the amazing times I've had playing in their world.After only an hour and a half, I can say without a doubt that this charming game is a gem and one I will enjoy watching develop even further.There is some nicely layered gameplay here with the RTS styled squad-based combat, base building and research opportunities. I have only skimmed the surface of this game but I can already tell I have many hours of fun ahead as I develop my army, base and economy.With the currently ongoing STEAM sale of Kenshi, I'd recommend jumping in now to support the developer in bringing this game to fruition as the little online research I have already done reveals that there is much more fun to be had in the comming months!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has come a long way from its humble beginning. Even at the early stage it was very playable. Since then more features and improvements have been made. I like the fact that the dev does not rush things and in doing so I can see this game having a very large fan base when its finally completed. Its difficult to describe this game accurately as it contains many well thought out ideas. Its a great combination of things and because death comes swiftly to the unwary you actually start to care about each individual member of your group. They are vulnerable like any human and require training and experience. As this takes time you can get quite upset should one day your group get attacked by a large group of bandits and many members die or become seriously injured. Its this level of detail that makes the game so rewarding because you have to actually think rather than just throw a bunch of disposable, easily respawned soldiers into battle as you would in other RTS games. In Kenshi a human life is a valuable commodity.
